Question_1.Context: The study investigated the uptake of PLGA nanoparticles by murine macrophage RAW264.7 cells using fluorescence microscopy. The experiment involved assessing the internalization of nanoparticles of different sizes by the cells.
Question_1.Question: What was the primary method used to assess the uptake of PLGA nanoparticles by RAW264.7 cells?
Question_1.Source: We assessed the variations in the uptake of APC-labelled PLGA-NH2 nanoparticles by RAW264.7 cells based on size following a 24-h incubation period (Fig. 2).

Question_2.Context: The study focused on the biodistribution of 89Zr-PLGA-NH2 nanoparticles in mice following different routes of administration. The experiment involved monitoring the distribution of nanoparticles in major organs over a specified period.
Question_2.Question: Which organ exhibited the highest initial distribution of nanoparticles after intravenous administration in mice?
Question_2.Source: In mice that were intravenously administered nanoparticles, we observed substantial distribution of the nanoparticles in the liver (28.3 ± 13.61%ID/g), lungs (14.76 ± 0.8%ID/g), and spleen (5.96 ± 2.04%ID/g).

Question_3.Context: The study examined the influence of nanoparticle size on cellular uptake in vitro using RAW264.7 cells. The experiment involved assessing the uptake of fluorescently labelled PLGA-NH2 nanoparticles of different sizes by the cells.
Question_3.Question: Which size of nanoparticles showed the highest uptake by RAW264.7 cells after 24 hours of incubation?
Question_3.Source: After 24 h, RAW264.7 cells exhibited a preference for 300- and 900-nm nanoparticles, whereas the uptake of 600-nm nanoparticles was lower than that of the other nanoparticles.

Question_4.Context: The study investigated the biodistribution of 89Zr-PLGA-NH2 nanoparticles in major tissues following intramuscular and subcutaneous injections in mice. The experiment involved tracking the distribution of nanoparticles in different tissues after administration via these routes.
Question_4.Question: Which route of administration resulted in the least distribution of nanoparticles in the lungs in mice?
Question_4.Source: In the case of intramuscular and subcutaneous injections, most nanoparticles remained around the injection site throughout the tracking period, with only a small quantity being eliminated by the kidneys.

Question_5.Context: The study examined the biodistribution of 89Zr-PLGA-NH2 nanoparticles in mice following intravenous and intranasal administrations. The experiment involved monitoring the distribution of nanoparticles in major organs over a specified period.
Question_5.Question: Which route of administration resulted in the highest pulmonary uptake of nanoparticles in mice?
Question_5.Source: In our in vivo experiments, radiolabelled nanoparticles exhibited significantly higher pulmonary uptake when administered intranasally rather than intravenously.

Question_6.Context: The study focused on the uptake of PLGA-NH2 nanoparticles by lung immune cells in mice following intranasal administration. The experiment involved quantifying nanoparticle uptake by different immune cell subsets in the lungs at various time points.
Question_6.Question: Which type of immune cells consistently exhibited a trend toward increased nanoparticle uptake compared to lymphoid immune cells?
Question_6.Source: Across all observed time points, immune cell subsets, including alveolar macrophages, dendritic cells (DCs), monocytes, and neutrophils, consistently exhibited a trend toward increased nanoparticle uptake compared to lymphoid immune cells.

Question_7.Context: The study investigated the biodistribution of 89Zr-PLGA-NH2 nanoparticles in major tissues following intravenous and intranasal administrations in mice. The experiment involved tracking the distribution of nanoparticles in different organs over a specified period.
Question_7.Question: Which organ exhibited the most substantial distribution of nanoparticles after intranasal administration in mice?
Question_7.Source: In the case of nasal administration, a persistent distribution of nanoparticles in the lungs was observed throughout the study period.

Question_8.Context: The study examined the uptake of PLGA-NH2 nanoparticles by lung immune cells in mice following intranasal administration. The experiment involved quantifying nanoparticle uptake by different immune cell subsets in the lungs at various time points.
Question_8.Question: Which immune cell subset consistently demonstrated a relatively higher tendency for nanoparticle uptake than lymphoid immune cells?
Question_8.Source: Myeloid immune cells consistently demonstrated a relatively higher tendency for nanoparticle uptake than lymphoid immune cells, irrespective of the time after nanoparticle administration.

Question_9.Context: The study focused on the biodistribution of 89Zr-PLGA-NH2 nanoparticles in major tissues following intravenous and intranasal administrations in mice. The experiment involved monitoring the distribution of nanoparticles in different organs over a specified period.
Question_9.Question: Which route of administration resulted in the least distribution of nanoparticles in the liver in mice?
Question_9.Source: Furthermore, nanoparticle accumulation in the liver and spleen of mice in the nasal administration group was almost negligible compared with that among mice in the intravenous administration group.

Question_10.Context: The study investigated the uptake of PLGA-NH2 nanoparticles by lung immune cells in mice following intranasal administration. The experiment involved quantifying nanoparticle uptake by different immune cell subsets in the lungs at various time points.
Question_10.Question: Which immune cell subset exhibited a sharp decline in nanoparticle uptake at 12 hours post-administration?
Question_10.Source: DCs exhibited a sharp decline in nanoparticle uptake at 12 h, with the lowest uptake level among myeloid immune cells at 48 h.

Question_11.Context: The study investigated the effect of alkaline hydrogen peroxide pretreatment on exhausted olive pomace to enhance its in vitro rumen digestibility for animal feedstock. It optimized conditions using a central composite experimental design.
Question_11.Question: What was the measured phenolic content for treated olive pomace (TOP) under optimized conditions?
Question_11.Source: Under the optimized conditions, the measured phenolic content was 1.51 ± 0.03 mg/100 g dry weight (DW) for treated olive pomace (TOP) (source: Results section)

Question_12.Context: The study examined the yields of crude proteins, neutral detergent fibers, and acid detergent fibers for treated olive pomace (TOP) compared to untreated exhausted olive pomace (EOP).
Question_12.Question: Which component had a significantly higher yield in TOP compared to EOP?
Question_12.Source: The crude proteins yield of TOP was 3.320 ± 0.05 g/100 g of DW, significantly more important than that of untreated EOP (source: Results section)

Question_13.Context: The study evaluated the reducing sugar yield for treated olive pomace (TOP) compared to exhausted olive pomace (EOP) using enzymatic hydrolysis.
Question_13.Question: What was the reducing sugar yield for TOP after enzymatic hydrolysis?
Question_13.Source: The reducing sugar yield from hydrolysis of TOP after 48 h was 48.0% (source: Results section)

Question_14.Context: The study investigated the potential gas production and in vitro organic matter digestibility of treated olive pomace (TOP) compared to exhausted olive pomace (EOP) using rumen fluid.
Question_14.Question: What was the potential gas production value for TOP compared to EOP?
Question_14.Source: The potential gas production value of TOP was significantly higher at 41.371 ml/g DM compared to EOP at 25.771 ml/g DM (source: Table 5)

Question_15.Context: The study focused on the effects of alkaline hydrogen peroxide treatment on the chemical composition of exhausted olive pomace (EOP) and treated olive pomace (TOP).
Question_15.Question: Which component showed a decrease in content for TOP compared to EOP?
Question_15.Source: The acid detergent lignin content in TOP was significantly lower compared to EOP (source: Table 3)

Question_16.Context: The study analyzed the fatty acid composition of exhausted olive pomace (EOP) and treated olive pomace (TOP) to evaluate the impact of alkaline hydrogen peroxide treatment.
Question_16.Question: Which fatty acid showed an increase in content for TOP compared to EOP?
Question_16.Source: The fatty acid C16:0 (palmitic acid) content increased in TOP compared to EOP (source: Table 4)

Question_17.Context: The study assessed the in vitro organic matter digestibility and metabolizable energy of treated olive pomace (TOP) and exhausted olive pomace (EOP) to determine their suitability as animal feedstock.
Question_17.Question: What was the in vitro organic matter digestibility value for TOP compared to EOP?
Question_17.Source: The in vitro organic matter digestibility value of TOP was higher at 26.73% compared to EOP at 24.76% (source: Table 5)

Question_18.Context: The study investigated the kinetics of gas production from rumen fermentation of treated olive pomace (TOP) and exhausted olive pomace (EOP) to evaluate their digestibility.
Question_18.Question: Which sample showed a higher gas production value after 96 hours of fermentation?
Question_18.C: Both had the same gas production
Question_18.Source: The gas production for TOP was higher at 31.67 ml/300 mg of DM compared to EOP at 21.66 ml/300 mg of DM after 96 hours of fermentation (source: Table 5)

Question_19.Context: The study focused on the optimization of alkaline hydrogen peroxide treatment using a central composite design to enhance the quality of olive pomace for animal feedstock.
Question_19.Question: What were the designated low and high levels of NaOH concentration in the central composite design?
Question_19.Source: The designated low and high levels of NaOH concentration were set between 1% (w/v) and 6% (w/v) (source: Optimization of alkaline hydrogen peroxide treatment using central composite design section)

Question_20.Context: The study investigated the effects of alkaline hydrogen peroxide treatment on the phenolic content and lipid oxidation of exhausted olive pomace to optimize the treatment efficiency.
Question_20.Question: What was the lipid oxidation value for treated olive pomace (TOP) under optimized conditions?
Question_20.Source: The lipid oxidation value for TOP under optimized conditions was 3.28 ± 0.05 mM MDA eq/kg of DW (source: Results section)

Question_21.Context: Functional composite materials are essential for addressing various challenges in the twenty-first century. The journal Functional Composite Materials focuses on the concept of functionality in composite materials.

Question_21.Source: The key requirement for publication is that the concept of functionality must be, clearly demonstrated.

Question_22.Question: Which of the following is NOT mentioned as an application of functional composite materials?
Question_22.Source: Functional composite materials for applications in construction, food packaging and space exploration.

Question_23.Context: The journal Functional Composite Materials covers a wide range of disciplines related to composite materials.
Question_23.Question: Which of the following disciplines is NOT mentioned as being covered by the journal?
Question_23.Source: Functional Composite Materials is an interdisciplinary journal focusing on fundamental and applied aspects of composite materials spanning chemistry, physics, biology, engineering, manufacturing, modelling, theory and materials.

Question_24.Context: Authors publishing in Functional Composite Materials benefit from unrestricted access and retain copyright under a Creative Commons license.
Question_24.Question: What benefit do authors receive by publishing in Functional Composite Materials?
Question_24.Source: Authors will benefit from their papers receiving unrestricted access around the world, as well as retaining copyright under a Creative Commons licence.

Question_25.Question: What aspect of composite materials must be clearly demonstrated for publication in the journal?
Question_25.Source: The key requirement for publication is that the concept of functionality must be, clearly demonstrated.

Question_26.Question: What role do functional composite materials play in addressing challenges according to the text?
Question_26.Source: Functional composite materials will play a major and wide-ranging role in addressing these challenges.

Question_27.Context: The journal Functional Composite Materials covers a broad spectrum of composite material functionalities.
Question_27.Question: Which of the following is NOT mentioned as a functionality of composite materials in the text?
Question_27.Source: Examples include, but are not limited to, electrical and thermal conductivity/insulation; thermoelectric; magnetic; optical; shape memory; ferroelectric; energy storage; phase change and antimicrobial.

Question_28.D: Chemistry, physics, biology, engineering, and more

Question_29.Context: The growth in materials discovery provides a wide range of starting materials for composite materials with various functionalities.
Question_29.Question: What does the growth in materials discovery provide for composite materials?
Question_29.C: A wide range of starting materials
Question_29.Source: Materials discovery continues unabated and the growth and application of new materials provides a cornucopia of starting materials.

Question_30.Context: Functional Composite Materials is an open access journal that offers benefits to authors through copyright retention and global access.

Question_30.Source: Authors will benefit from their papers receiving unrestricted access around the world, as well as retaining copyright under a Creative Commons licence.

Question_31.Context: The study investigated the effect of polymers on zinc oxide (ZnO) nanofluids for enhanced oil recovery. The stability of nanofluids was evaluated using sedimentation and UV–vis spectrophotometry tests.
Question_31.Question: What was noted about the stability of ZnO nanofluids with PVA and PVP stabilizers compared to ZnO nanofluids without stabilizing agents?
Question_31.Source: ZnO, ZnO + PVP, and ZnO + PVA were all set in stable conditions and their color changes were observed while their photos were recorded each day for comparison purposes. All the nanofluids were well stirred and ultrasonicated to obtain a homogenous solution and after 24 h. there was no change in color which means that the nanofluids displayed good stability.

Question_32.Context: The study focused on the stability analysis of nanofluids suspension in the base fluid using visual tests for seven days.
Question_32.Question: What was observed about the stability of ZnO nanofluids with PVA and PVP stabilizers after seven days?
Question_32.C: They showed no change in color
Question_32.Source: On the seventh day of observation, ZnO nanofluids agglomerated and settled faster than ZnO + PVA and ZnO + PVA meanwhile ZnO + PVA has the best stability compared to ZnO and ZnO + PVP nanofluids.

Question_33.Context: The study conducted UV–Vis absorbance spectra measurement of ZnO nanofluids at different wavelengths.
Question_33.Question: What was observed about the absorbance values of ZnO nanofluids with stabilizing agents at different concentrations?
Question_33.A: Absorbance values decreased with increasing concentrations
Question_33.B: Absorbance values increased with increasing concentrations
Question_33.C: Absorbance values were the same at different concentrations
Question_33.D: Absorbance values were not affected by stabilizing agents
Question_33.Source: It has been observed that absorbance values increase with the increase in concentrations and decrease with increasing wavelength and this corresponds to Zeta potential values which is above − 43.7 (mV) showing good stability of ZnO nanofluids.

Question_34.Context: The study focused on the contact angle measurement of different fluids on a PDMS surface.
Question_34.Question: What was observed about the contact angle of ZnO nanofluids with PVA and PVP stabilizers compared to DI water on PDMS surface?
Question_34.C: Contact angle was the same for all fluids
Question_34.Source: It was observed that DI water has a higher contact angle compared to nanofluids and this is because PDMS is hydrophobic and hardly changes in pure water. However, the contact angle decreased by 30% when the PVP stabilizer was added to ZnO nanofluids and further decreased by 35% for the PVA stabilizer as well.

Question_35.Context: The study conducted IFT measurements to determine the effect of ZnO nanofluids and stabilizing agents on interfacial tension.
Question_35.Question: What was noted about the interfacial tension reduction when ZnO nanofluids with stabilizing agents were introduced?
Question_35.Source: Further decrease in IFT was also observed when nanofluid containing PVP and PVA stabilizing agents were introduced then the IFT decreased by 59 and 61% respectively.

Question_36.Context: The study focused on the oil recovery factors of various nanofluid concentrations in a microchannel matrix.
Question_36.Question: Which nanofluid recorded the highest recovery factor in the microchannel matrix experiment?
Question_36.D: The recovery factor was the same for all nanofluids
Question_36.Source: Results showed that ZnO + PVA nanofluids has a higher recovery of 82% followed while ZnO + PVP recorded the second higher recovery factor of 78% and ZnO nanofluids therefore, recorded the lowest recovery factor of 73% respectively.

Question_37.Context: The study examined the residual oil saturation after flooding in a PDMS microchannel matrix.
Question_37.Question: What was observed about the residual oil saturation after flooding with ZnO nanofluids?
Question_37.Source: It was observed when ZnO nanofluids were used, almost 45% of saturated oil remained unrecovered in the pore media.

Question_38.Context: The study focused on the visualization of porous media during the flooding process.
Question_38.Question: What was observed about the sweep efficiency when nanofluids with stabilizing agents were used?
Question_38.Source: Based on the visualization of porous media, nanofluids with stabilizing agents displayed a better sweep efficiency than ZnO nanofluids.

Question_39.Context: The study examined the effectiveness of ZnO nanofluids on enhanced oil recovery in a microchannel matrix.
Question_39.Question: What was the recovery factor of ZnO nanofluids in the microchannel matrix experiment?
Question_39.D: The recovery factor was not mentioned
Question_39.Source: Microchannel matrix flooding experiment results showed that ZnO nanofluids were able to enhance oil by 73%.

Question_40.Context: The study concluded by summarizing the findings related to the stability and effectiveness of ZnO nanofluids for enhanced oil recovery.
Question_40.Question: What was the main conclusion of the study regarding the stability and effectiveness of ZnO nanofluids for enhanced oil recovery?
Question_40.C: ZnO nanofluids were stable and effective
Question_40.Source: The results of the IFT pendant test revealed that PVA and PVP nanofluids significantly reduced the IFT by 59 and 61% compared to ZnO nanofluids without stabilizing agents. It was also noted that the alteration of formation wettability increases mobility and entropy of nanoparticles in suspension resulting in a reduction of IFT, increase in disjoining pressure, and creation of pressure profile in the reservoir.

Question_41.Context: The paper discusses the modeling of plasticity in polycrystals using crystal plasticity models.

Question_41.A: Using a single crystal model for each grain
Question_41.C: Ignoring grain boundaries in the model
Question_41.Source: The standard way of modeling plasticity in polycrystals is by using the crystal plasticity model for single crystals in each grain...

Question_42.Question: What is the main advantage of the diffuse-interface crystal plasticity model?
Question_42.B: It allows for the modeling of grain boundary processes
Question_42.C: It eliminates the need for boundary conditions
Question_42.D: It focuses only on single crystal behavior
Question_42.Source: The aim of this paper is to present a framework that preserves the ability to model intra-grain plasticity, while at the same time enabling a straightforward generalization to include grain boundary processes...

Question_43.A: To understand the chemical composition of the material

Question_43.C: To determine the color of the material
Question_43.D: To study the electrical conductivity of the material
Question_43.Source: The study of texture evolution is important because textured metals typically exhibit plastic anisotropy, which plays a significant role on mechanical properties...

Question_44.Context: The paper discusses the decomposition of the deformation gradient into lattice and plastic parts.
Question_44.Question: What is the purpose of decomposing the deformation gradient into lattice and plastic parts?
Question_44.B: To separate the effects of dislocation slip and lattice deformation
Question_44.C: To eliminate the need for boundary conditions
Question_44.D: To focus only on the macroscopic stress-strain response
Question_44.Source: For single crystals, a multiplicative kinematic decomposition of the deformation gradient into elastic and plastic parts is typically used. This decomposition adequately describes the distinctly different kinematical mechanisms that operate during the plastic deformation of a crystal...

Question_45.Context: The paper discusses the construction of a stress-free polycrystal by imposing specific initial conditions.

Question_45.A: By applying a constant stress to each grain
Question_45.B: By imposing a piecewise constant rotation field and its transpose
Question_45.C: By ignoring the effects of dislocation slip
Question_45.Source: To make the resulting model numerically tractable, we regularize the piecewise constant rotation field, resulting in a diffuse interface model, that preserves the zero-stress character of the grain boundaries...

Question_46.B: It allows for the modeling of grain boundary energies

Question_46.D: It eliminates the need for initial conditions

Question_47.Question: How does the diffuse-interface model enable the modeling of grain boundary processes?
Question_47.A: By ignoring the effects of grain boundaries
Question_47.B: By representing grain boundaries as geometrically necessary dislocations
Question_47.C: By using a continuum plasticity model
Question_47.D: By focusing only on single crystal behavior
Question_47.Source: To this end, we develop a 'diffuse'-interface crystal plasticity model for polycrystalline materials based on a representation of grain boundaries as a special subclass of geometrically necessary dislocations...

Question_48.A: To demonstrate the robustness of the crystal plasticity model

Question_48.C: To study the effects of temperature on polycrystal plasticity

Question_49.A: Dislocations are not considered in the model
Question_49.B: Dislocations are the basic defect carriers
Question_49.C: Dislocations are used to model grain boundaries
Question_49.D: Dislocations are ignored in the evolution of FP

Question_51.Context: The paper discusses the application of a quantum classification algorithm in distinguishing metallic states from insulating states of vanadium dioxide (VO2).
Question_51.Question: What was the parameter used to determine the minimum inner product between the centroid vector and arbitrary vectors with the same sublabel in the classification of metallic and insulating states of VO2?

Question_52.Context: The paper discusses the classification of randomly generated data using a quantum classification algorithm.
Question_52.Question: How many sublabels were obtained from the training data in the classification of randomly generated data?
Question_52.Source: After appropriate learning process, 54 sublabels (22 for red and 32 for blue) are obtained from the training data.

Question_53.Context: The paper discusses the classification of entanglement in Werner states using a quantum classification algorithm.
Question_53.Question: How many test data points were used in the classification of entanglement in Werner states?
Question_53.Source: We prepared 200 entangled states and 200 untangled states as the test data.

Question_54.Context: The paper discusses the classification of entanglement in Werner states using a quantum classification algorithm.
Question_54.Question: How many points were predicted with wrong labels when the training set contained 32 points?
Question_54.Source: In (a), the training set only contains 32 points, and we keep them all as sublabels. So that there are 7 qubits in the classification circuit (5 for sublabels and 2 for test data). 12 points are predicted with wrong label.

Question_55.Context: The paper discusses the classification of entanglement in Werner states using a quantum classification algorithm.
Question_55.Question: How many points were predicted with wrong labels when the training set contained 64 points?
Question_55.Source: In (b) the training set contains 64 points and all are kept as sublabels, and there are 8 qubits in the classification circuit. Finally 8 points are predicted with wrong labels.

Question_56.Context: The paper discusses the classification of entanglement in Werner states using a quantum classification algorithm.
Question_56.Question: How many points were predicted with wrong labels when the training set contained 128 points?
Question_56.Source: In (c) there are 128 points in the learning set and we derived 64 sublabels. Similarly as (b) we need 8 qubits to build the classification circuit, and only 6 qubits are predicted with wrong sublabels.

Question_57.Context: The paper discusses the application of a quantum classification algorithm in distinguishing metallic states from insulating states of vanadium dioxide (VO2).
Question_57.Question: How many sublabels were required for the insulating states and metallic states in the classification of VO2?
Question_57.Source: Finally we need 7 sublabels for insulating states and 8 sublabels for metallic states, which means that the classification circuit consists of 5 qubits (4 for sublabels as control qubit and 1 for data).

Question_58.Context: The paper discusses the application of a quantum classification algorithm in distinguishing metallic states from insulating states of vanadium dioxide (VO2).
Question_58.Question: What was the reason for the error in prediction when Pressure (P) or Temperature (T) was small in the classification of metallic and insulating states of VO2?
Question_58.A: Few vectors in these areas were used in the training process.
Question_58.Source: The error appears because of the fact that few vectors in these areas where used in the training process.

Question_59.Context: The paper discusses the application of a quantum classification algorithm in distinguishing metallic states from insulating states of vanadium dioxide (VO2).
Question_59.Question: What was the significance of mapping data into [0, 2π] × [0, 2π] in the classification of metallic and insulating states of VO2?
Question_59.A: To focus on the performance at low temperature.
Question_59.D: To speed up the quantum algorithm.
Question_59.Source: To get a better prediction results, an option is to map both training data and test data into [0, π] × [0, π] instead of [0, 2π] × [0, 2π]. However, here we do not focus on the performance at low temperature, nor the phase transition about P = 20GPa. As a result, mapping data into [0, 2π] × [0, 2π] is still an acceptable choice.

Question_60.Context: The paper discusses the application of a quantum classification algorithm in distinguishing metallic states from insulating states of vanadium dioxide (VO2).
Question_60.Question: What was the method used to classify vectors in higher dimensional space?
Question_60.C: Both Mapping method I and II
Question_60.D: No method was discussed for higher dimensional space.
Question_60.Source: Depending on the structure of qubits, two different mapping methods can be used: Mapping method I and Mapping method II.

Question_61.Context: The study investigated the toxic effects of TiO2 NRs and TiO2 NRs loaded with Ag or Au NPs on boar spermatozoa.
Question_61.Question: What was the observed effect on sperm motility after incubation with Ag-TiO2 NRs compared to controls?
Question_61.Source: After incubation for 2 h, motility was significantly greater for non-treated controls than in the other groups, and the motility of sperm incubated with 20 μg/ml of Ag-TiO2 NRs was significantly less than in the other groups.

Question_62.Context: The study assessed sperm viability and acrosomal integrity after incubation with TiO2 NRs, Ag-TiO2 NRs, or Au-TiO2 NRs.
Question_62.Question: What was the effect on sperm viability after treatment with 20 μg/ml Ag-TiO2 NRs compared to controls?
Question_62.Source: Percentages of viable sperm were higher after treatment with 10 μg/ml Au-TiO2 NRs and for controls than after treatment with 20 μg/ml Ag-TiO2 NRs.

Question_63.Context: The study examined the intracellular ROS levels in spermatozoa exposed to TiO2 NRs, Ag-TiO2 NRs, or Au-TiO2 NRs.
Question_63.Question: Which treatment resulted in significantly higher intracellular ROS levels in spermatozoa?
Question_63.Source: Interestingly, ROS levels were found to be significantly higher after treatment with Ag-TiO2 NRs than for the other treatments.

Question_64.Context: The study investigated the fertilization rates and embryo developments of oocytes inseminated with sperm incubated with TiO2 NRs, Ag-TiO2 NRs, or Au-TiO2 NRs.
Question_64.Question: Which treatment resulted in the lowest blastocyst formation rate?
Question_64.Source: When oocytes were fertilized with spermatozoa incubated with 20 μg/ml Ag-loaded TiO2 NRs, the lowest blastocyst rates were observed.

Question_65.Context: The study examined the electron transfer mechanism in spermatozoa exposed to Ag-loaded TiO2 NRs.
Question_65.Question: What is the role of NADPH in the electron transfer mechanism?
Question_65.Source: We observed higher ROS levels when NADPH (0.2 mM) and Ag-loaded TiO2 NRs were treated in combination; ROS production was low when only NADPH was administered.

Question_66.Context: The study assessed the effect of Ag or Au NPs incorporated on TiO2 NRs on boar spermatozoa.
Question_66.Question: What was the observed effect on sperm viability after treatment with 10 μg/ml Au-TiO2 NRs compared to controls?
Question_66.Source: Percentages of viable sperm were higher after treatment with 10 μg/ml Au-TiO2 NRs and for controls than after treatment with 20 μg/ml Au-TiO2 NRs.

Question_67.Context: The study examined the charge transfer mechanism and ROS generation in spermatozoa exposed to Ag-loaded TiO2 NRs.
Question_67.Question: What is the proposed charge transfer mechanism between living cells and Ag-TiO2 NRs?
Question_67.A: Electron transfer from Ag-TiO2 NRs to living cells
Question_67.B: Electron transfer from living cells to Ag-TiO2 NRs
Question_67.C: Proton transfer from Ag-TiO2 NRs to living cells
Question_67.D: Proton transfer from living cells to Ag-TiO2 NRs
Question_67.Source: The electron donor ligand of Ag NP might accept the transmembrane electrons of sperm enzymatic NADPH after mitochondrial electron transport chain reactions have been disrupted.

Question_68.Context: The study investigated the effects of Ag or Au NPs incorporated on TiO2 NRs on boar spermatozoa.
Question_68.Question: What was the observed effect on sperm motility after incubation with 10 μg/ml Au-TiO2 NRs compared to controls?
Question_68.Source: The percentage of total motile sperm after 10 min of incubation was higher for sperm treated with 10 μg/ml Au-TiO2 NRs than for sperm treated with 20 μg/ml Ag-TiO2 NRs.

Question_69.Context: The study assessed the intracellular ROS levels in spermatozoa exposed to TiO2 NRs, Ag-TiO2 NRs, or Au-TiO2 NRs.
Question_69.Question: Which treatment resulted in significantly lower intracellular ROS levels in spermatozoa?
Question_69.Source: ROS levels were found to be significantly higher after treatment with Ag-TiO2 NRs than for the other treatments.

Question_70.Context: The study examined the fertilization rates and embryo developments of oocytes inseminated with sperm incubated with TiO2 NRs, Ag-TiO2 NRs, or Au-TiO2 NRs.
Question_70.Question: Which treatment resulted in the highest cleavage rate after in vitro fertilization?
Question_70.Source: We observed more cleaved oocytes from IVF performed using control sperm than in the other groups.

Question_71.Context: Based on the experiment with the E. coli-H strain in the microbial electrolysis cell system, what was the observed effect of electricity on levoglucosan consumption and ethanol production?
Question_71.Question: What effect did the application of electricity have on levoglucosan consumption and ethanol production by the E. coli-H strain?
Question_71.A: Decreased levoglucosan consumption and ethanol production
Question_71.B: No significant change in levoglucosan consumption but increased ethanol production
Question_71.C: Increased levoglucosan consumption and ethanol production
Question_71.D: Increased levoglucosan consumption but decreased ethanol production
Question_71.Source: In electrically treated bio-oil media, the E. coli-H strain exhibited significantly higher levoglucosan consumption and ethanol production capacities compared with the control.

Question_72.Context: In the experiment, what was the bioethanol yield obtained by the E. coli-H strain in the electrified MEC system?
Question_72.Question: What was the bioethanol yield achieved by the E. coli-H strain in the electrified MEC system?
Question_72.Source: E. coli-H produced 0.54 g ethanol/g levoglucosan, reaching 94% of the theoretical yield.

Question_73.Context: Regarding inhibitor degradation performance, what was the observed effect of electricity on furfural conversion in the bio-oil-based microbial electrolysis cell system?
Question_73.Question: How did the application of electricity affect furfural conversion in the bio-oil-based microbial electrolysis cell system?
Question_73.Source: In the bioelectrochemical group, the concentration of furfural had dropped to approximately 2 × 10–8 mg/L at 56 h, which compares with the value of approximately 8.83 × 10–8 mg/L recorded at the same time point in the control fermentation.

Question_74.Context: What was the observed trend in Coulomb efficiency during the fermentation process in the MEC system?
Question_74.Question: What trend was observed in Coulomb efficiency during the fermentation process in the MEC system?
Question_74.Source: The Coulomb efficiency of the experimental group peaked at 80.3%, 66.8%, and 28.4% during the course of fermentation from 32 to 36 h, 36 h to 40 h, and 40 h to 44 h, respectively, thereby indicating that external energy is the main source for generating bioethanol during the fermentation process, although gradually declines in the latter stages.

Question_75.Context: What was the purpose of using neutral red in the experiment with E. coli in the microbial electrolysis cell system?
Question_75.Question: Why was neutral red used in the experiment with E. coli in the microbial electrolysis cell system?
Question_75.Source: Neutral red functions as a supplementary electron sink that accepts the excessive electrons produced during glycolysis, which are in turn used to regenerate NAD+ from NADH, which is beneficial for further glycolysis.

Question_76.Context: What was the observed effect of electricity on the growth of E. coli in the experiment?
Question_76.Question: How did the application of electricity affect the growth of E. coli in the experiment?
Question_76.Source: Notably, the application of electricity clearly stimulated the growth of E. coli and markedly diminished the necessary fermentation time.

Question_77.Context: What was the main benefit of the MEC system in the production of ethanol according to the experiment?
Question_77.Question: What was the primary advantage of the MEC system in ethanol production based on the experiment?
Question_77.Source: We conclude that the ethanol produced from the integrated process demonstrated in this study can be used to derive fuel from hydrodeoxygenated bio-oil, while reducing lifecycle greenhouse gas emissions.

Question_78.Context: What was the observed effect of the MEC system on inhibitor conversion in the bio-oil media?
Question_78.Question: How did the MEC system influence inhibitor conversion in the bio-oil media?
Question_78.Source: These findings thus indicate that microbial electrolysis can promote the efficient conversion of the organic acids and furfural in bio-oil.

Question_79.Context: What was the significance of the observed Coulomb efficiency in the MEC process?
Question_79.Question: Why is the Coulomb efficiency important in the MEC process?
Question_79.C: To assess the efficiency of bioethanol production
Question_79.Source: The Coulomb efficiency for the production of ethanol in the MEC process represents the ratio of the mass of ethanol liberated by a current to the theoretical mass, as predicted by Coulomb’s law.

Question_80.Context: What was the conclusion drawn regarding the application of the microbial electrosynthesis process for ethanol production?
Question_80.Question: What conclusion was reached regarding the use of the microbial electrosynthesis process for ethanol production?
Question_80.C: Enhanced ethanol productivity and reduced emissions
Question_80.Source: We conclude that the ethanol produced from the integrated process demonstrated in this study can be used to derive fuel from hydrodeoxygenated bio-oil, while reducing lifecycle greenhouse gas emissions.

Question_81.Context: The study focused on investigating the synergistic effects of cutting parameters on surface roughness in ball end milling of oxygen-free high conductivity (OFHC) copper.
Question_81.Question: Which experimental design was used for the study?
Question_81.Source: Firstly, an experimental plan based on a full factorial rotatable central composite design with variable parameters, the cutting feed rate or feed per tooth, axial depth of cut, radial depth of cut, and the cutting speed, was developed.

Question_82.Context: The study aimed to determine a statistical model that can suitably correlate the experimental results.
Question_82.Question: What was the range for each variable in the experimental plan?
Question_82.Source: The range for each variable was varied through five different levels.

Question_83.Context: The study concluded that the step over or radial depth of cut had a significant influence on the surface roughness of the milled OFHC copper.
Question_83.Question: Which parameter had the highest contribution to the surface roughness model?
Question_83.Source: The surface roughness model suggests that the radial depth of cut provides the primary contribution (45.81%) and influences most significantly on the surface roughness.

Question_84.Context: The study highlighted the importance of selecting proper process parameters for achieving good surface finish.
Question_84.Question: Which method was used for developing models and quantifying the relationship between roughness and its parameters?
Question_84.Source: The different methods include that confined in this approach response surface method (RSM), factorial designs, and Taguchi methods.

Question_85.Context: The study emphasized the significance of end milling in various industries.
Question_85.Question: What is a key parameter in the machining process that is important for product quality?
Question_85.Source: Usually, the product quality is measured by its surface roughness. Minimizing the surface roughness results in a product with good surface finish of the final machined part.

Question_86.Context: The study discussed the demand for good quality finished OFHC Cu material.
Question_86.Question: What is the main application of OFHC Cu in electrical industries?
Question_86.Source: Presently, the demand for good quality of finished OFHC Cu material (like a mirror finish surface) is increasing at a brisk pace for its use in various sectors, like manufacturing, electrical, electronics, nuclear, and medical science.

Question_87.Context: The study highlighted the importance of end milling in various industries.
Question_87.Question: Which material was used for the end milling process in the study?
Question_87.Source: The present study was performed on the OFHC Cu.

Question_88.Context: The study emphasized the importance of selecting proper process parameters for achieving good surface finish.
Question_88.Question: Which method was used for modeling and optimization of the end milling process parameters?
Question_88.Source: Lakshmi et al. used RSM for modeling and optimization of the end milling process parameters.

Question_89.Context: The study discussed the importance of reducing effort and minimizing machining time and cost.
Question_89.Question: Which approach was used to predict the surface roughness in the machining process?
Question_89.Source: Among the various approaches used to predict the surface roughness, the present article demands a brief review of roughness modeling using RSM.

Question_90.Context: The study focused on developing a statistical model to predict surface roughness in high-speed flat end milling.
Question_90.Question: What was the material used for high-speed flat end milling in the study?
Question_90.Source: Ozcelik et al. developed a statistical model to predict the surface roughness in high-speed flat end milling of AISI 1040 steel.

Question_91.Context: The study focused on producing superhydrophobic electrospun fibrous mats from PHBV/SiO2 composites. The incorporation of SiO2-NPs and surface modification with SA were key aspects of the experiment.
Question_91.Question: What was the purpose of incorporating SiO2-NPs into the electrospinning solutions?
Question_91.Source: Incorporation of SiO2-NPs changes the wetting state to a Wenzel non-wetting state caused by the partial encapsulation of the NPs within the fiber morphology, which creates the required fiber surface roughness.

Question_92.Context: The study involved modifying the static wetting behavior of fibrous mats by incorporating SiO2-NPs into the electrospinning solutions.
Question_92.Question: How did the incorporation of SiO2-NPs affect the initial water contact angles of the fibrous mats?
Question_92.D: Changed the water contact angles to 90°
Question_92.Source: The obtained initial WCAs for different SiO2 concentration were in the range of 125° to 141°.

Question_93.Context: The study explored the effects of surface modification with SA on the PHBV/SiO2 composite fibers.
Question_93.Question: What was the main purpose of surface modification with SA?
Question_93.Source: The composite fiber mats were surface modified via interaction with SA to facilitate a dynamic roll-off by inducing a tertiary roughness upon the plasticization of PHBV/SiO2 composites.

Question_94.Context: The study involved analyzing the thermal properties of PHBV fibers following the incorporation of SiO2-NPs and surface modification with SA.
Question_94.Question: How did the incorporation of SiO2-NPs and SA modification affect the melting temperature of PHBV fibers?
Question_94.Source: The thermal analysis demonstrated that the incorporation of SiO2-NPs and plasticization by SA decreased the crystallinity and altered the melting temperature of PHBV.

Question_95.Context: The study included FTIR analysis to characterize the chemical interactions in the PHBV/SiO2 composite fibers.
Question_95.Question: What was the main finding regarding the interaction between SiO2-NPs and PHBV in the composite fibers?
Question_95.A: Chemical bonding between SiO2-NPs and PHBV
Question_95.B: Physical incorporation of SiO2-NPs into the composite
Question_95.Source: The SiO2-NPs were incorporated into the PHBV fiber matrix and apparently did not influence the chemical structure of the PHBV matrix.

Question_96.Context: The study investigated the wettability behavior of the fibrous surfaces before and after surface modification with SA.
Question_96.Question: What was the primary outcome of the surface modification with SA in terms of wettability?
Question_96.Source: Surface modified beadless microfiber composites showed improved static WCAs in the range of 145.8° ± 2.7°, relative to WCAs observed during the droplet collapse measurements.

Question_97.Context: The study aimed to create superhydrophobic fibrous surfaces using a combination of SiO2-NPs incorporation and SA surface modification.
Question_97.Question: What was the primary advantage of the surface modified MNS bilayer composite?
Question_97.Source: SA modified MNS bilayer of the PHBV/SiO2 composite is an ideal design for superhydrophobic fibrous surfaces, characterized by the highest contact angle of approximately 155.3° and roll-off angle of less than 4°.

Question_98.Context: The study explored the effects of SiO2-NPs incorporation on the fiber morphology and wetting behavior of the PHBV fibrous mats.
Question_98.Question: What change was observed in the fiber morphology with the addition of SiO2-NPs?
Question_98.Source: The incorporation of NPs created surface roughness in each case. This roughness was, however, more pronounced in the beaded nanofibers than the beadless microfibers.

Question_99.Context: The study focused on the thermal properties of PHBV fibers following surface modification with SA.
Question_99.Question: How did the surface modification with SA affect the melting enthalpy of the PHBV fibers?
Question_99.D: Changed the melting enthalpy to 50 J/g
Question_99.Source: The interaction of the polar groups of SA molecules with the PHBV fibrous mats presumably affects the intramolecular structures of the PHBV chains. This altering of the PHBV structure decreases the degree of crystallinity which can be predicted from the lowering of melting enthalpy after surface modification of PHBV fibers.

Question_100.Context: The study included FTIR analysis to characterize the chemical interactions in the PHBV/SiO2 composite fibers.
Question_100.Question: What was the main finding regarding the interaction between SA and PHBV in the composite fibers?
Question_100.A: Physical incorporation of SA into the composite
Question_100.B: Chemical bonding between SA and PHBV
Question_100.Source: FTIR analysis confirmed the interaction of the polar carboxyl groups of SA with the PHBV chains; however, the successful plasticization of PHBV/SiO2 composites is limited to low SA concentrations.

Question_101.Context: Radiopharmaceuticals containing [177mLu]lutetium can pose challenges due to its physical half-life and concentration. What is the radionuclidic purity required for [177Lu]lutetium according to the European Pharmacopoeia?
Question_101.Question: What is the radionuclidic purity required for [177Lu]lutetium according to the European Pharmacopoeia?
Question_101.Source: According to the European Pharmacopoeia, [177Lu] lutetium for radiolabeling must have a radionuclidic purity of greater than 99%.

Question_102.Question: What is the exemption limit for [177mLu]lutetium to be considered safe for unrestricted release of solid and liquid substances?
Question_102.Source: For [177mLu]lutetium, the exemption limit is 1 × 10^6 Bq and 0.1 Bq/g for the unrestricted release of solid and liquid substances.

Question_103.Context: What is the physical half-life of [177mLu]lutetium?
Question_103.Question: What is the physical half-life of [177mLu]lutetium?
Question_103.Source: The physical half-life of [177mLu]lutetium is 160.4 days.

Question_104.Source: In the first case where [177mLu]lutetium decays to [177Lu]lutetium, the main gamma emission is 497 keV.

Question_107.Source: The problem that might arise in some nuclear medicine facilities is related to the exemption limit of 5 × 10^5 Bq/m3 in the waste water.

Question_108.Source: For the test synthesis with approved LuMark® (IDB Holland), the radionuclidic impurity of [177mLu]lutetium was 0.008248%.

Question_151.Context: The study focused on analyzing the behavior of hoop stress and stress concentration factors in thick-walled cylinders with radial cross bores under internal pressure. The aim was to determine the impact of cross bore size and thickness ratio on stress levels.

Question_151.B: To analyze the impact of temperature on stress concentration factors.
Question_151.C: To establish the optimal Stress Concentration Factors (SCF) in thick-walled cylinders with radial cross bores.
Question_151.D: To investigate the effect of external pressure on stress distribution in cylinders.
Question_151.Source: The aim of this study was to determine the behaviour of the hoop stress as well as to establish the optimal Stress Concentration Factors (SCF).

Question_152.C: Thickness ratios from 3.0 to 1.4 and cross bore size ratios from 0.1 to 1.0.
Question_152.D: Thickness ratios from 2.5 to 4.0 and cross bore size ratios from 0.3 to 0.8.
Question_152.Source: Cylinders of thickness ratios of 3.0 down to 1.4 with cross bore size ratios (cross bore to main bore ratio) ranging from 0.1 to 1.0 were studied.

Question_161.Context: Understanding the browning process in cigar tobacco leaves (CTLs) after harvest.
Question_161.Question: Which enzyme is responsible for the oxidation of polyphenols to quinones in CTLs?
Question_161.Source: Enzymatic browning is the oxidation of polyphenols to quinones by the action of polyphenol oxidase (PPO) and peroxidase (POD), followed by the formation of brown pigments by polymerization of these quinones and their derivatives.

Question_162.Context: Investigating the metabolic pathways involved in CTL browning.
Question_162.Question: Which metabolic pathway has an important effect on enzymatic browning in CTLs?
Question_162.Source: The metabolic pathways with important effects on enzymatic browning were phenylpropanoid biosynthesis, flavonoid biosynthesis, isoquinoline alkaloid biosynthesis, phenylalanine metabolism, and linoleic acid metabolism.

Question_163.Context: Analyzing the changes in chemical composition during the air-curing process of CTLs.
Question_163.Question: Which compound content decreased rapidly during the yellowing phase of CTLs?
Question_163.Source: All compounds except polyacids and ions were rapidly degraded during the yellowing phase, especially the chlorophyll content.

Question_164.Context: Identifying the major amino acids involved in the browning reaction of CTLs.
Question_164.Question: Which amino acid was identified as one of the major amino acids involved in the browning reaction of CTLs?
Question_164.Source: Hierarchical cluster analysis discovered glutamate, serine, threonine, ornithine, and arginine as the major amino acids involved in the browning reaction.

Question_165.Context: Exploring the physiological changes in CTLs during the air-curing process.
Question_165.Question: At approximately which day did the browning reaction reach its peak intensity in CTLs?
Question_165.Source: The browning reaction was most intense at approximately 12 d when polyphenol oxidase and peroxidase activities reached their maximum.

Question_166.Context: Investigating the chemical composition changes in CTLs during air-curing.
Question_166.Question: Which compound content was relatively stable during the air-curing process of CTLs?
Question_166.Source: The polyacids were relatively stable, with low contents of malonic acid and succinic acid.

Question_167.Context: Analyzing the metabolites discovered in CTLs during the air-curing process.
Question_167.Question: Which metabolite was mainly enriched in fresh tobacco leaves and the yellowing stage?
Question_167.Source: Cyanidin were mainly enriched in fresh tobacco leaves and the yellowing stage.

Question_168.Context: Understanding the impact of amino acids on the browning reaction of CTLs.
Question_168.Question: Which amino acid was mainly enriched in fresh tobacco leaves and then degraded through amino acid metabolic pathways during air-curing?
Question_168.Source: Ornithine, citrulline, serine, and glutamic acid were mainly enriched in fresh tobacco leaves and then degraded through amino acid metabolic pathways.

Question_169.Context: Investigating the role of organic acids in regulating browning in CTLs.
Question_169.Question: Which organic acid mainly regulated the browning reaction in the middle and late air-curing periods of CTLs?
Question_169.Source: Lycopene, citric acid, fumaric acid, and 2-oxoglutaric acid mainly regulated the browning reaction in the middle and late air-curing periods.

Question_170.Context: Exploring the impact of metabolic pathways on CTL browning.
Question_170.Question: Which metabolic pathway was mainly enriched in the browning process of CTLs?
Question_170.Source: The important pathways affecting DAMs in the air-curing process were mainly phenylpropanoid biosynthesis, alanine, aspartate, and glutamate metabolism, tryptophan metabolism, flavonoid biosynthesis, isoquinoline alkaloid biosynthesis, phenylalanine metabolism, and linoleic acid metabolism.

Question_171.Context: The study focused on producing butyric acid from pre-treated rape straw using simultaneous enzymatic hydrolysis semi-solid fermentation (SEHSF).
Question_171.Question: What was the optimized butyric acid yield under optimal conditions?
Question_171.Source: The optimized butyric acid yield was as high as 13.86 ± 0.77 g/L, which was 2.1 times higher than that of the initial screening. Furthermore, under optimal conditions, the yield of butyric acid was 13.42 ± 0.83 g/L in a 2.5-L fermentor.

Question_172.Context: The study aimed to develop a high-yield, green, and economical process for the production of butyric acid by lignocellulose fermentation.
Question_172.Question: What was the main carbon source used in the fermentation medium for butyric acid production?
Question_172.Source: The biosynthesis pathway of butyric acid from glucose and xylose in C. beijerinckii BRM001 was constructed by combining the related metabolic reactions together.

Question_173.Context: The study optimized the fermentation medium composition based on genome annotation.
Question_173.Question: Which nitrogen source was selected as the best inorganic nitrogen source for fermentation to produce butyric acid?
Question_173.Source: Therefore, ammonium acetate is the best inorganic nitrogen source.

Question_174.Context: The study conducted a single factor experiment to optimize the fermentation medium components.
Question_174.Question: What was the optimal amount of yeast powder determined for butyric acid production?
Question_174.Source: After 9 days of static fermentation at 35 °C, the content of butyric acid was measured. From the results, it can be concluded that the optimum amount was 1 g/L yeast powder.

Question_175.Context: The study utilized response surface methodology to optimize the fermentation conditions.
Question_175.Question: Which factor had an extremely significant effect on the concentration of butyric acid?
Question_175.Source: The first terms X1 and X2 of the model are extremely significant, X3 and X4 are significant, the interaction term X1X2 is significant, and the rest are not significant.

Question_176.Context: The study conducted non-sterile fermentation of butyric acid to evaluate industrial application potential.
Question_176.Question: What was the yield of butyric acid produced under non-sterile fermentation conditions in a 2.5-L fermentor?
Question_176.Source: The yield of butyric acid increased from 13.16 ± 0.46 g/L to 13.89 ± 0.72 g/L, which was 1.06 times higher than that before optimization.

Question_177.Context: The study focused on the biosynthesis pathways of amino acids and vitamins in C. beijerinckii BRM001.
Question_177.Question: What effect does the amount of tryptophan have on protein synthesis?
Question_177.Source: The amount of tryptophan will directly affect the rate of protein synthesis.

Question_178.Context: The study investigated the essential growth factors for microorganisms.
Question_178.Question: Which growth factor is essential for microorganisms?
Question_178.Source: Biotin is an essential growth factor for microorganisms.

Question_179.Context: The study analyzed the metabolic characteristics of C. beijerinckii BRM001 by genome sequencing and annotation.
Question_179.Question: What was the main carbon source explored for the production of butyric acid?
Question_179.Source: The glucose and xylose were the main two carbohydrates in rape straw hydrolysate.

Question_180.Context: The study aimed to optimize the fermentation conditions for butyric acid production.
Question_180.Question: What was the optimal fermentation time determined for butyric acid production?
Question_180.Source: The optimal fermentation time of C. beijerinckii BRM001 was determined to be 9 days, and the highest butyric acid yield was 13.02 ± 0.71 g/L.

Question_181.Context: Gas sensors play a crucial role in detecting pollutants. The study focuses on improving the recovery rate of NO2 sensors using heterojunctions.
Question_181.Question: What is the purpose of forming heterojunctions between transition metal dichalcogenide nanosheets and ZnO nanoparticles?
Question_181.A: To decrease the sensitivity of the sensor
Question_181.B: To increase the operating temperature of the sensor
Question_181.C: To improve the recovery rate of the sensor
Question_181.D: To reduce the sensing response of the sensor
Question_181.Source: Herein, heterojunctions were formed between the two-dimensional transition metal dichalcogenide nanosheets and zero-dimensional ZnO nanoparticles to improve the recovery rate of a NO2 sensor.

Question_182.Context: The study discusses the advantages of using metal oxide-based gas sensors.
Question_182.Question: What advantages do metal oxide-based gas sensors offer?
Question_182.B: Complex synthesis process and high toxicity
Question_182.D: High operating temperatures and difficult synthesis
Question_182.Source: Gas sensors based on TMDC, such as MoS2, WS2, and WSe2, can detect NO2 and NH3 gases at room temperature owing to their distinctive layered structures, unique photoelectric and charge transfer properties, air stability, and presence of abundant active sites.

Question_183.Context: The study mentions the challenges associated with TMDC-based gas sensors.
Question_183.Question: What are the major limitations of TMDC-based NO2 gas sensors?
Question_183.B: Low sensitivity, slow response, and poor recovery
Question_183.C: Rapid recovery and low detection limit
Question_183.D: Stable recovery and high detection limit
Question_183.Source: Low sensitivity, slow response, and poor recovery are the major limitations associated with TMDC-based NO2 gas sensors.

Question_184.Context: The study explains the impact of forming heterojunctions on sensor recovery rates.
Question_184.Question: How did the recovery rates of MoS2/ZnO and WSe2/ZnO sensors improve compared to MoS2 and WSe2 sensors?
Question_184.Source: Compared with MoS2 and WSe2, the recovery rates of MoS2/ZnO and WSe2/ZnO sensors improved by ~ 5.72–11.87% and ~ 8.10–19.44%, respectively.

Question_185.Context: The study discusses the role of ZnO nanoparticles in reducing signal drift.
Question_185.Question: How do ZnO nanoparticles affect the signal drift of TMDC-based sensors?
Question_185.B: Have no impact on signal drift
Question_185.D: Cause the signal drift to fluctuate
Question_185.Source: Furthermore, the addition of ZnO nanoparticles significantly reduces the signal drift of the TMDC-based sensor.

Question_186.Context: The study explains the mechanism behind the improved recovery rate of TMDC/ZnO-based gas sensors.
Question_186.Question: What leads to the formation of a depletion layer on the ZnO surface in the heterojunction?
Question_186.Source: The electrons of ZnO near the ZnO/TMDC interface tend to diffuse into TMDC, whereas the holes in TMDC tend to diffuse into ZnO before the Fermi levels of the p-type TMDC and n-type ZnO reach equilibrium.

Question_187.Context: The study highlights the impact of NO2 gas on the conductivity of the sensor.
Question_187.Question: What happens to the sensor conductivity when exposed to NO2 gas?
Question_187.C: Conductivity decreases initially and then increases
Question_187.Source: When the sensor is exposed to NO2 gas, the NO2 molecules first capture electrons from ZnO with large adsorption energy and increase the width of the built-in electric field, resulting in a decrease in the sensor conductivity at the initial stage of NO2 gas influx.

Question_188.Context: The study discusses the impact of incomplete desorption of NO2 molecules on sensor recovery rates.
Question_188.Question: How does incomplete desorption of NO2 molecules affect the recovery rate of TMDC/ZnO-based gas sensors?
Question_188.A: It has no effect on the recovery rate
Question_188.Source: This significantly improves the recovery rate of TMDC/ZnO-based gas sensors.

Question_189.Context: The study concludes by emphasizing the contribution of heterojunctions to gas sensor performance.
Question_189.Question: What is the expected contribution of the study to the development of NO2 gas sensors?
Question_189.Source: This study is expected to contribute to the development of high-performance NO2 gas sensors.

Question_190.Context: The study acknowledges the funding support received for the research.
Question_190.Question: What was the source of funding for the research mentioned in the paper?
Question_190.C: Ministry of Science, ICT, and Future Planning
Question_190.Source: This research was supported by the Basic Science Research Program of the National Research Foundation of Korea (NRF), funded by the Ministry of Science, ICT, and Future Planning (2022R1A2C4001577).

Question_191.Context: The paper discusses the detection of Chromium III (Cr3+) ions using 4-mercaptobenzoic acids (4-MBA)-functionalized silver-coated gold nanoparticles (Au@Ag NPs).
Question_191.Question: What was the optimal concentration of 4-MBA for the detection system?
Question_191.Source: The results showed that metal ions would coordinate with 4-MBA with different force. 4-MBA-Au@Ag NPs could react with Cr3+ ions when the concentration of 4-MBA was 10^−7 M. In addition, there was no reaction with other metal ions. Then, the colorimetric performance was enhanced with the increasing of the 4-MBA concertation. However, there was an obvious reaction between other metal ions and 4-MBA when the concentration was 10^−5 M.

Question_192.Context: The paper discusses the detection of Chromium III (Cr3+) ions using 4-mercaptobenzoic acids (4-MBA)-functionalized silver-coated gold nanoparticles (Au@Ag NPs).
Question_192.Question: What was determined as the colorimetric detection limit for Cr3+ ions?
Question_192.Source: The results showed that there was a correlation curve between the Cr3+ ion concentration, and the ratio of the absorbance at 650 nm and 410 nm from 10 μM to 500 μM for 4-MBA-Au@Ag NPs and the R2 was 0.993. Besides, the limit of detection can reach 9 μM.

Question_193.Context: The paper discusses the detection of Chromium III (Cr3+) ions using 4-mercaptobenzoic acids (4-MBA)-functionalized silver-coated gold nanoparticles (Au@Ag NPs).
Question_193.Question: What was found to be the optimal pH value for the detection system?
Question_193.Source: The results showed that the pH value had a great effect on the UV–Vis spectrum and colorimetric image. The signals were weak between blanks and the detected samples from 3 to 5. Then, the signal gradually increased with the increasing of pH value. Meanwhile, the signal reached the plateau between blanks and the detected samples when the pH was 9.

Question_194.Context: The paper discusses the detection of Chromium III (Cr3+) ions using 4-mercaptobenzoic acids (4-MBA)-functionalized silver-coated gold nanoparticles (Au@Ag NPs).
Question_194.Question: What was the recovery range of the system for Cr3+ ions detection?
Question_194.Source: The recovery of the system was estimated to be from 88.2 to 112.1%, which was satisfactory for practical analysis of samples.

Question_195.Context: The paper discusses the detection of Chromium III (Cr3+) ions using 4-mercaptobenzoic acids (4-MBA)-functionalized silver-coated gold nanoparticles (Au@Ag NPs).
Question_195.Question: What was the correlation coefficient for the relationship between Cr3+ ion concentration and the ratio of absorbance at 650 nm and 410 nm?
Question_195.Source: The results showed that there was a correlation curve between the Cr3+ ion concentration, and the ratio of the absorbance at 650 nm and 410 nm from 10 μM to 500 μM for 4-MBA-Au@Ag NPs and the R2 was 0.993.

Question_196.Context: The paper discusses the detection of Chromium III (Cr3+) ions using 4-mercaptobenzoic acids (4-MBA)-functionalized silver-coated gold nanoparticles (Au@Ag NPs).
Question_196.Question: What metal ion concentration range was used to evaluate the detection sensitivity of 4-MBA-Au@Ag NPs?
Question_196.Source: The results showed that there was a correlation curve between the Cr3+ ion concentration, and the ratio of the absorbance at 650 nm and 410 nm from 10 μM to 500 μM for 4-MBA-Au@Ag NPs and the R2 was 0.993.

Question_197.Context: The paper discusses the detection of Chromium III (Cr3+) ions using 4-mercaptobenzoic acids (4-MBA)-functionalized silver-coated gold nanoparticles (Au@Ag NPs).

Question_197.B: Fe2+, Al3+, Ni2+, Sr2+, La3+, Cu2+, Ce3+, Co2+

Question_199.Context: The paper discusses the detection of Chromium III (Cr3+) ions using 4-mercaptobenzoic acids (4-MBA)-functionalized silver-coated gold nanoparticles (Au@Ag NPs).
Question_199.Question: What was the role of the 4-MBA in the detection process?
Question_199.C: To provide color to the solution
Question_199.Source: The detection platform mainly relied on the coordination between Cr3+ ions and the group of –COOH of 4-MBA. The pH value had a great effect of the coordination reaction owing to the statues of the group of –COOH.

Question_200.Context: The paper discusses the detection of Chromium III (Cr3+) ions using 4-mercaptobenzoic acids (4-MBA)-functionalized silver-coated gold nanoparticles (Au@Ag NPs).
Question_200.Question: What was the conclusion regarding the selectiveness of the probe?
Question_200.A: The probe showed selectivity towards all tested metal ions
Question_200.B: The probe showed selectivity only towards Cr3+ ions
Question_200.C: The probe showed no selectivity towards any metal ions
Question_200.D: The probe showed selectivity towards some metal ions but not all
Question_200.Source: The results showed that only the exposure to Cr3+ ions led to the obvious signal changes, while the exposure to other tested ions does not cause any appreciable change in the peak of 4-MBA-Au@Ag NPs. In addition, there was an apparent color change in 4-MBA-Au@Ag after exposure to Cr3+ ions, and other ions could not cause the same color changes under the same conditions.

Question_201.Context: The study focused on optimizing the production of 68Ga-labeled radiotracers using a microfluidic cassette-based iMiDEV™ radiosynthesizer. The researchers explored different mixing techniques for radiolabeling.
Question_201.Question: What mixing technique was found to be the most effective for achieving high radiolabeling yield?
Question_201.Source: The pulse flow technique allowed high radiochemical yields and reproducibility. It also ensures consistent and dependable radiochemical yield by addressing mixing and bubble formation problems from the slow elution of [68Ga]Ga3+ and the buffer-peptide mixture.

Question_202.Context: The researchers optimized the elution of [68Ga]GaCl3 to improve the recovery from the Chromafix PS-H + resin. Different eluent concentrations and volumes were tested for direct and reverse trapping and elution of [68Ga]GaCl3.
Question_202.Question: What was the optimized eluent concentration for the elution of [68Ga]GaCl3?
Question_202.Source: The elution pressure was optimized from 1 bar to 0.65 bar, resulting in improved product elution from R4 with minimal loss of product activity on R4. The elution concentration was adjusted to 0.15 M HCl in 5 M NaCl (eluent 2).

Question_203.Context: The study evaluated the impact of different reaction times on the radiolabeling yield. Initially, a reaction time of 5 minutes was chosen, but it resulted in a low radiochemical yield.
Question_203.Question: What was the optimized reaction time that significantly improved the radiolabeling yield?
Question_203.Source: The reaction time was extended to 10 minutes, resulting in a significant improvement in the radiolabeling yield of up to 86%. Consequently, the 10-minute reaction time was consistently maintained for all subsequent syntheses.

Question_204.Context: The researchers explored the impact of different precursor amounts on the radiochemical yield. Initially, a test with 10 µg of precursor yielded quantitative results in manual synthesis.
Question_204.Question: What was the precursor amount that was found to optimize the radiochemical conversion and reproducibility?
Question_204.Source: When the amount of precursor increased, the radiochemical yield increased for both FAPI-46 and DOTA-TOC. Nevertheless, poor mixing also contributed to the suboptimal radiochemical yield of [68Ga]Ga-FAPI-46 (53 ± 1%; decay corrected; n = 2) and [68Ga]Ga-DOTA-TOC (41 ± 5%; decay corrected; n = 2) even though 40 µg of the precursor was used for the synthesis.

Question_205.Context: The study validated the experimental conditions in a different research center to assess the reproducibility of results. The same experimental settings and synthesis recipes were maintained for the validation runs.
Question_205.Question: What was the radiochemical yield achieved for [68Ga]Ga-FAPI-46 in the validation run at a different research center?
Question_205.Source: After the end of the synthesis, quality control tests were performed. The radiochemical yield of [68Ga]Ga-FAPI-46 achieved using the pulse flow approach was 51 ± 5% (decay corrected; n = 13).

Question_206.Context: The study compared the radiochemical yield of [68Ga]Ga-FAPI-46 using the iMiDEV™ microfluidic module with two other conventional modules. The radiochemical yields were satisfactory for a single dose or DOD requirement.
Question_206.Question: How did the radiochemical yield of [68Ga]Ga-FAPI-46 using the iMiDEV™ module compare to the conventional Modular-Lab Pharmtracer from Eckert and Ziegler?
Question_206.Source: The lower yield from the iMiDEV™ could be explained by the increased synthesis time and inadequate mixing of reagents because of the bead filling of the different cassette batches.

Question_207.Context: The study demonstrated the potential of microfluidic methods for efficient and reliable radiometal-based radiopharmaceutical synthesis. The researchers optimized various parameters, including reaction temperature, precursor amount, and purification method.
Question_207.Question: What was the optimized precursor concentration used for both [68Ga]Ga-FAPI-46 and [68Ga]Ga-DOTA-TOC syntheses?
Question_207.Source: The precursor amount was optimized to 15 µg for both [68Ga]Ga-FAPI-46 and [68Ga]Ga-DOTA-TOC syntheses, resulting in improved radiochemical conversion and reproducibility.

Question_208.Context: The study investigated the impact of different elution strategies on the recovery of [68Ga]GaCl3. Two eluent concentrations were evaluated for their efficiency in trapping and elution processes.
Question_208.Question: Which eluent concentration was found to be more effective for the recovery of [68Ga]GaCl3?
Question_208.Source: The eluent concentration of 0.15 M HCl in 5 M NaCl was determined to be more effective in trapping and eluting [68Ga]GaCl3, leading to improved recovery rates compared to other concentrations.

Question_209.Context: The study explored the impact of different elution volumes on the trapping and elution efficiency of [68Ga]GaCl3. Various elution volumes were tested to optimize the recovery process.
Question_209.Question: Which elution volume was found to optimize the trapping and elution efficiency of [68Ga]GaCl3?
Question_209.Source: The elution volume of 5 mL was identified as the optimal volume for trapping and eluting [68Ga]GaCl3, ensuring efficient recovery and minimal loss during the process.

Question_210.Context: The study focused on the optimization of the reaction temperature for radiolabeling processes. Different temperatures were tested to determine the most suitable conditions for high radiochemical purity.
Question_210.Question: What was the optimized reaction temperature for the radiolabeling process?
Question_210.Source: The optimized reaction temperature for the radiolabeling process was set at 90°C, which resulted in improved radiochemical purity and efficiency during the synthesis of [68Ga]Ga-labeled radiotracers.

Question_211.Context: The study focused on the in vitro production of CTP using a six-enzyme cascade system. One of the enzymes involved in the cascade was cytidine deaminase (CDA).
Question_211.Question: What was the optimal pH for the activity of the screened cytidine deaminase (CDA) in the study?
Question_211.Source: The effect of pH on the enzyme activity was analyzed under different pH values, and the remaining two enzymes had maximum activity at pH 7.0. Both enzymes maintained at least 60% of their highest activity at pH 5.0, indicating a match with the first-stage reaction conditions.

Question_212.Context: The study involved the screening and characterization of cytidine deaminases from extremophilic sources.

Question_212.Source: To investigate the optimum pH of SsCDA, SrCDA, and TgCDA, the enzyme activity was analyzed under different pH values. Except for SsCDA, which did not exhibit deaminase activity under any of the conditions tested, the remaining two enzymes had maximum activity at pH 7.0.

Question_213.Context: The study involved the modification of the rate-limiting enzyme CTP synthase in the pathway.
Question_213.Question: What was the specific activity of the I19T/R34G/R262H variant of CTP synthase compared to the wild type?
Question_213.Source: The specific activity of the I19T/R34G/R262H variant was 2.68 U/mg, while the wild enzyme had a specific activity of 1.55 U/mg.

Question_214.Context: The study involved the optimization of Zn2+ concentration for cytidine deaminase.
Question_214.Question: What was the effect of increasing Zn2+ concentration on the rate of uridine production by SrCDA?
Question_214.Source: Unexpectedly, increasing Zn2+ concentration slowed down the rate of uridine production by SrCDA, indicating that the enzyme did not require Zn2+ to assist catalysis.

Question_215.Context: The study involved the directed evolution of CTP synthase to relieve feedback inhibition.
Question_215.Question: Which mutation site contributed the most to the increase in activity of the I19T/R34G/R262H variant of CTP synthase?
Question_215.Source: The I19T mutation contributed the most to the increase in activity, with the specific activity of the I19T/R34G/R262H variant being 1.7 times higher than that of the wild enzyme.

Question_216.Context: The study involved the kinetic analysis of the wild enzyme and the variant for the substrates ATP and UTP.
Question_216.Question: What was the effect of the I19T/R34G/R262H variant on the affinity for UTP compared to the wild enzyme?
Question_216.Source: The I19T/R34G/R262H variant had a significantly lower affinity for UTP compared to the wild enzyme, indicating that the substitution of threonine for isoleucine disrupted the binding site for UTP.

Question_217.Context: The study involved the in vitro six-enzyme cascade synthesis of CTP.
Question_217.Question: What was the final yield of CTP obtained after 10.0 hours of the reaction?
Question_217.Source: After optimizing the reaction conditions, 16.5 mM CTP was accumulated in 10.0 h with a yield of more than 82%.

Question_218.Context: The study involved the structural analysis of the I19T/R34G/R262H variant of CTP synthase.
Question_218.Question: What was the effect of the I19T mutation on the binding of the enzyme to ATP?
Question_218.Source: The replacement of the I19 site by a threonine added a new hydrogen bonding interaction between the enzyme and the substrate ATP, significantly enhancing the binding of the enzyme to ATP.

Question_219.Context: The study involved the kinetic analysis of the wild enzyme and the variant for the substrates ATP and UTP.
Question_219.Question: What was the effect of the I19T/R34G/R262H variant on the utilization of UTP compared to the wild enzyme?
Question_219.Source: The relieving of CTP inhibition by the I19T/R34G/R262H variant meant that the utilization of UTP reached a near 1:1 equilibrium with the rate of ATP utilization, resulting in an increase in apparent activity compared to the wild enzyme.

Question_220.Context: The study involved the in vitro six-enzyme cascade synthesis of CTP.
Question_220.Question: What was the remaining concentration of UMP detected after the CTP synthesis reaction?
Question_220.Source: After 8.0 h of reaction, 16.5 mM CTP was detected, with the remaining 0.5 mM UMP, 1.8 mM UDP, and 0.9 mM UTP.

Question_231.Context: Ion sputtering leads to the formation of surface roughness and patterns at the nanoscale. What did Habenicht study regarding the effect of ion fluence on surface dynamics?

Question_231.B: The influence of ion angle on surface morphology.
Question_231.C: The influence of ion fluence on surface roughness.
Question_231.D: The influence of substrate temperature on surface patterns.
Question_231.Source: Habenicht studied the effect of ion fluence on surface dynamics by exposing a highly ordered pyrolytic graphite (HOPG) surface with (0001) orientation to increasing levels of ion fluence.

Question_232.Context: What is the orientation of ripple structures observed on a silver surface when ion bombardment occurs at low temperatures?
Question_232.Question: What is the orientation of ripple structures observed on a silver surface when ion bombardment occurs at low temperatures?
Question_232.Source: The results showed that ion bombardment at low temperatures (160K) resulted in a rough surface, but as the temperature was raised to 290 K and above, a ripple structure began to appear aligned along the < 1¯10 > direction.

Question_233.A: To develop analytical and computational methods to further the understanding of surface pattern evolution under ion bombardment.
Question_233.B: To study the effects of stochastic noise on surface morphology.
Question_233.C: To investigate the role of surface stress in pattern formation.

Question_234.A: Formation of ripple structures at all angles.
Question_234.B: Formation of parallel ripple structures at all angles.

Question_234.D: Formation of concentric circular patterns at all angles.

Question_235.B: Experimental observations by Navez et al.
Question_235.C: The influence of ion fluence on surface roughness.
Question_235.D: The effects of stochastic noise on surface morphology.
