Question_585.Question: What was the primary component used to visually compare metabolomic variations between ABEs and GBEs?

Question_601.Context: Understanding soil-water content (SWC) is crucial for various processes. What is a common misconception regarding SWC and soil-moisture contents (SMCs)?
Question_601.Question: What is a common misconception regarding SWC and soil-moisture contents (SMCs)?
Question_601.A: SWCs and SMCs are interchangeable terms.
Question_601.B: SWCs account for the volume of water in a unit of soil volume.
Question_601.C: SMCs are more relevant for plant growth than SWCs.
Question_601.D: SWCs are not influenced by soil texture.
Question_601.Source: SWCs account for a ratio between the volume of water present in a unit of soil volume. It has been discovered that the rate of mineralization significantly affects the microbial contents and activity, which helps to regulate plant growth. SWCs are often confused with soil-moisture contents (SMCs), which in general are different.

Question_602.Context: Soil-water holding capacity (SWHC) is influenced by various factors. How does soil texture affect SWHC?
Question_602.Question: How does soil texture affect soil-water holding capacity (SWHC)?
Question_602.A: Finer-textured soils have lower SWHC than coarser-textured soils.
Question_602.B: Soil texture has no impact on SWHC.
Question_602.C: Clayey soils have higher SWHC than sandy soils.
Question_602.D: Sandy soils can hold more water than clayey soils.
Question_602.Source: In general, higher water-holding capacity is a feature of finer-textured soils (clayey soils) than coarser textured soils (sandy soils), because they have 8–10 times more total pore space and smaller pores that hold water more tightly.

Question_603.Context: The movement of water in soil pores is influenced by various factors. What determines the direction of water movement in or out of plant roots?
Question_603.Question: What determines the direction of water movement in or out of plant roots?
Question_603.Source: The water movement from soil to plant roots is justified by the suction phenomena elucidated by TACT theory (transpiration, adhesion, cohesion, and tension). The present theory elucidates the mechanism underlying water transport within the xylem and the generation of negative water potential within plant roots.

Question_604.Context: Soil texture plays a significant role in nutrient availability. How does soil texture influence nutrient retention and leaching?
Question_604.Question: How does soil texture influence nutrient retention and leaching?
Question_604.A: Finer-textured soils have higher nutrient leaching potential.
Question_604.B: Clayey soils can store more cations than sandy soils.
Question_604.C: Sandy soils have higher nutrient retention than clayey soils.
Question_604.D: Clayey soils have lower nutrient availability than sandy soils.
Question_604.Source: In general, finer-textured soils (finer than 1 mm) have higher soil nutrient concentrations than coarser-textured soils, because they have a larger surface area and a more negative charge on their surfaces that can adsorb cations.

Question_605.Context: Advancements in soil-water content (SWC) measurements have led to various techniques. What is a disadvantage of the gravimetric method (GM) for measuring SWC?
Question_605.Question: What is a disadvantage of the gravimetric method (GM) for measuring SWC?
Question_605.C: It cannot measure the same sample area again.
Question_605.D: It is not affected by soil bulk density.
Question_605.Source: The GM is a destructive approach that often fails to provide real-time knowledge and cannot measure the same sample area again.

Question_606.Context: Artificial intelligence (AI) is revolutionizing soil texture analysis. What is a key advantage of AI tools over conventional methods for soil texture prediction?
Question_606.Question: What is a key advantage of AI tools over conventional methods for soil texture prediction?
Question_606.C: AI tools provide subjective data analysis.
Question_606.D: AI tools reduce cost, time, and labor involved.
Question_606.Source: AI tools are a promising set of alternatives for these limitations that otherwise confine soil management. AI processing of these data sets mainly reduces the cost, time, and labor involved compared with conventional laboratory protocols.

Question_607.Context: Soil texture prediction using AI involves machine learning (ML) and deep learning (DL). What type of data sets are utilized by these algorithms for accurate soil texture predictions?
Question_607.Question: What type of data sets are utilized by machine learning (ML) and deep learning (DL) algorithms for accurate soil texture predictions?
Question_607.C: Compositional, spectral, and geographical data sets.
Question_607.Source: The inputs utilized by these algorithms are compositional, spectral, and geographical data sets that can be in non-numerical form.

Question_608.Context: The neutron method (NM) is a technique for measuring soil-water content. What is a limitation of the neutron method (NM)?
Question_608.Question: What is a limitation of the neutron method (NM) for measuring soil-water content?
Question_608.C: It requires calibration with other methods.
Question_608.D: It is not affected by tightly bound hygroscopic water molecules.
Question_608.Source: The NM was then developed for more likely real-time and non-destructive SWC measurements. However, it is expensive, hazardous, and requires calibration with other methods and correction for soil bulk density and temperature.

Question_609.Context: Ground penetration radar (GPR) is a method for measuring soil-water content. What is a disadvantage of the GPR method?
Question_609.Question: What is a disadvantage of the ground penetration radar (GPR) method for measuring soil-water content?
Question_609.C: It is not affected by soil texture.
Question_609.D: It does not require calibration with other methods.
Question_609.Source: This method is non-destructive, high-resolution, and capable of measuring SWC at different depths and large areas of soil. However, it is complex, expensive, and affected by soil texture, structure, salinity, and surface roughness.

Question_610.Context: The future of soil texture analysis involves integrating AI models seamlessly. What is a crucial challenge that needs to be addressed for successful implementation of AI-based soil texture analysis?
Question_610.Question: What is a crucial challenge that needs to be addressed for successful implementation of AI-based soil texture analysis?
Question_610.Source: However, addressing challenges related to data quality, interpretability, and system integration will be crucial for the successful implementation of AI-based soil texture analysis.

Question_621.Context: The study focused on investigating the effects of various factors on the electrical conduction of carbon/epoxy laminates.

Question_622.Question: What method was developed for testing the electrical conduction of carbon/epoxy laminates?

Question_623.B: Had no effect on electrical conductivity

Question_626.Question: What happened to the electrical conductivities as the current levels increased?

Question_627.B: Had no effect on electrical conductivity

Question_628.Source: Equation (4) predicts that the increase in clamping pressure at a given temperature should result in the increase in electrical conductivity.

Question_629.Context: The study discussed the impact of conductive paint on electrical conductivity.

Question_631.Context: The study aimed to determine the effect of LNX on exercise performance in aged mice.
Question_631.Question: What was the main lignan compound in the lignan-enriched nutmeg extract (LNX) used in the study?
Question_631.Source: The study mentions that LNX comprised the major lignan, nectandrin B, which was used to evaluate the effect on exercise performance in aged mice.

Question_632.Context: The study involved feeding aged mice with LNX for three weeks.
Question_632.Question: What anatomical change was observed in the soleus muscle of aged mice fed LNX?
Question_632.Source: The study reports that in aged mice fed LNX, the widths of the gastrocnemius and soleus muscles were increased in a dose-dependent manner.

Question_633.Context: The study evaluated the exercise performance of aged mice fed with LNX.
Question_633.Question: Which test showed a significant increase in endurance time in LNX-treated aged mice?
Question_633.Source: The study indicates that in the rotarod test, endurance time in the accelerating mode was increased in both LNX-treated aged groups, with a significant increase specifically in aged mice fed LNX.

Question_634.Context: The study involved proteomic analysis of the soleus muscle of aged mice.
Question_634.Question: Which protein was found to interact with actin and act as a hub protein in the protein-protein interaction network?
Question_634.Source: The protein-protein interaction network analysis revealed that actin, ACTA1, functions as a hub protein interacting with several myosin heavy chain isoforms.

Question_635.Context: The study involved analyzing the expression of specific proteins in the soleus muscle of aged mice fed with different concentrations of LNX.
Question_635.Question: Which protein showed a significant dose-dependent increase in expression in LNX-fed aged mice?
Question_635.Source: Immunoblot analysis confirmed the dose-dependent increase in the expression of Myh4 in the soleus muscles of aged mice fed with different concentrations of LNX.

Question_636.Context: The study aimed to identify core proteins induced by LNX feeding in the soleus muscle of aged mice.
Question_636.Question: Which protein was significantly decreased in expression by LNX feeding in aged mice?
Question_636.Source: The study indicates that the expression of LIM-binding protein 3 (Ldb3) was increased in aged mice but decreased by LNX administration, resulting in a young-like phenotype.

Question_637.Context: The study involved analyzing the proteome of the soleus muscle of aged mice fed with LNX.
Question_637.Question: What was the main GO group identified in the GO analysis of proteins commonly found in aged versus LNX-fed aged mice muscle?
Question_637.Source: The study mentions that the main GO groups identified in the GO analysis were related to components related to skeletal muscle, which falls under the biological process category.

Question_638.Context: The study involved constructing a protein-protein interaction network using the STRING database.
Question_638.Question: Which protein was found to interact with myosin isoforms and act as a hub protein in the network?
Question_638.Source: The protein-protein interaction network analysis revealed that actin, ACTA1, interacts with several myosin heavy chain isoforms and functions as a hub protein.

Question_639.Context: The study involved immunoblot analysis of specific proteins in the soleus muscle of aged mice fed with LNX.
Question_639.Question: Which protein showed a slight decrease in expression but was significantly increased in the expression of Myh1, Myh4, and Acta1 in a dose-dependent manner?
Question_639.Source: The study reports that Ttn showed a slight decrease in expression, while Myh1, Myh4, and Acta1 showed significant dose-dependent increases in expression in the soleus muscles of aged mice fed with different concentrations of LNX.

Question_640.Context: The study aimed to evaluate the effect of LNX on aging-related sarcopenia.
Question_640.Question: What was the conclusion regarding the potential of bioactive lignans of LNX as therapeutic agents?
Question_640.A: LNX could not be effective for aging-related sarcopenia.
Question_640.B: Bioactive lignans of LNX have no potential as therapeutic agents.
Question_640.C: LNX could be developed as potential therapeutic agents for aging-related sarcopenia.
Question_640.D: Bioactive lignans of LNX are harmful for muscle health.
Question_640.Source: The study concludes that LNX could be effective for aging-related sarcopenia, and the bioactive lignans of LNX could be developed as potential therapeutic agents.

Question_641.Context: The paper discusses the phase transition from jamming to pinning in dislocation systems.
Question_641.Question: What is the main focus of the study?
Question_641.A: The effect of precipitate density on dislocation motion.
Question_641.B: The interaction between dislocations and obstacles in crystals.
Question_641.C: The use of machine learning in dislocation dynamics simulations.
Question_641.D: The impact of shear stress on crystal yielding.
Question_641.Source: While deforming, crystalline materials change irreversibly through discrete plastic events, originating from the collective motion of dislocations – the topological defects of the crystal lattice.

Question_642.Context: The study employs three-dimensional discrete dislocation dynamics simulations with varying density of fully coherent precipitates.
Question_642.Question: What method is used to study the phase transition from jamming to pinning?
Question_642.Source: Here we employ three-dimensional discrete dislocation dynamics simulations with varying density of fully coherent precipitates to study this phase transition − from jamming to pinning − using unsupervised machine learning.

Question_643.Context: The paper discusses the impact of introducing disorder to crystals on dislocation motion.
Question_643.Question: What effect does introducing disorder to a crystal have on dislocations?
Question_643.A: It increases the crystal's mechanical strength.
Question_643.B: It decreases the crystal's mechanical strength.
Question_643.C: It has no effect on the crystal's mechanical strength.
Question_643.D: It alters the crystal's chemical composition.
Question_643.Source: However, crystals are rarely completely pure, and introducing some disorder − such as precipitates − to the crystal to impede dislocation motion can increase the crystal’s mechanical strength.

Question_644.Context: The study focuses on the collective behavior of dislocations in crystals.
Question_644.Question: What are dislocations in the context of crystal lattice?
Question_644.Source: While deforming, crystalline materials change irreversibly through discrete plastic events, originating from the collective motion of dislocations – the topological defects of the crystal lattice.

Question_645.Context: The paper discusses the use of machine learning in studying phase transitions in dislocation systems.
Question_645.Question: What role does machine learning play in the study?
Question_645.A: To predict the exact phase transition point.
Question_645.B: To distinguish between different phases based on evolving dislocation configurations.
Question_645.C: To analyze the chemical composition of the crystals.
Question_645.D: To measure the mechanical strength of the crystals.
Question_645.Source: To address this problem, we use machine learning (ML). ML is proving to be a flexible and useful tool for physics and materials science... and here we applied the unsupervised ’confusion’ scheme introduced in Van Nieuwenburg et al. (2017).

Question_646.Context: The study involves simulations of FCC aluminum with varying density of fully coherent precipitates.
Question_646.Question: What parameter is systematically increased to observe the phase transition from jamming to pinning?
Question_646.Source: Our recent study of 3D discrete dislocation dynamics (DDD) simulations of FCC aluminum with the inclusion of stationary fully coherent precipitates... showed that, by systematically increasing the strength or density of the precipitates, the system goes from the phase of dislocation-interaction dominated jamming to disorder-dominated pinning.

Question_647.Context: The paper discusses the impact of obstacles on dislocation motion in crystals.
Question_647.Question: What effect do obstacles have on dislocations in a crystal?
Question_647.C: They alter the chemical composition of the crystal.
Question_647.D: They have no effect on dislocation motion.
Question_647.Source: The key point here is that obstacles to dislocation motion may change the system behaviour by inducing dislocation pinning.

Question_648.Context: The study involves the characterization of evolving dislocation configurations during constant loading.
Question_648.Question: What descriptors are used to characterize the evolving dislocation configurations?
Question_648.A: Dislocation junction lengths, geometric necessary dislocation density, and dislocation correlation.
Question_648.B: Crystal lattice orientation, chemical impurities, and disordered regions.
Question_648.C: Dislocation density, crystal lattice orientation, and mechanical strength.
Question_648.D: Geometric anomalies, chemical composition, and crystal lattice orientation.
Question_648.Source: To accomplish this we computed the dislocation junction lengths, geometrically necessary dislocation (GND) density and dislocation correlation, and used these separately to describe the microstructure for the ML algorithm.

Question_649.Context: The study discusses the use of principal component analysis in reducing the dimensionality of data.
Question_649.Question: What is the purpose of using principal component analysis in the study?
Question_649.A: To increase the complexity of the data.
Question_649.B: To visualize the data in higher dimensions.
Question_649.C: To reduce the dimensionality of the data.
Question_649.D: To introduce noise to the data.
Question_649.Source: The three distinct data sets (different descriptors) were cast to lower dimensions by principal component analysis (PCA).

Question_650.Context: The study discusses the classification of dislocation systems using linear discriminant analysis.
Question_650.Question: What method is used for classification in the study?
Question_650.Source: For a classifier, our choice was based on linear discriminant analysis (LDA)...

Question_651.Context: The study investigated the effects of different composite passivators on the physiology and biochemistry of Chinese cabbage.

Question_651.B: Reduction of reactive oxygen species production

Question_654.Source: The direct effects on the activity of antioxidant enzymes were greatest for soluble protein content.

Question_655.Question: Which factor had the greatest direct effect on Cd content, BCF, and TF in Chinese cabbage petioles?
Question_655.Source: The direct effects of soluble protein content on petiole Cd content, BCF, and TF were greater than those of other factors.

Question_656.Context: The study explored the effects of passivators on the oxidative stress response of Chinese cabbage.
Question_656.Question: What was the main factor influencing the reduction of MDA content in Chinese cabbage?
Question_656.Source: T3, T4, and T5 treatments significantly reduced the MDA content in the leaf and petiole cells, indicating that passivator application can reduce the degree of oxidative stress.

Question_657.Context: The study focused on the interactions between different factors influencing Cd toxicity in Chinese cabbage.
Question_657.Question: Which factor had the greatest direct effect on Cd TF in Chinese cabbage petioles?
Question_657.Source: The direct effect of the Cd TF on Chinese cabbage petioles was greatest for soluble protein content.

Question_658.Context: The study analyzed the physiological adaptations of Chinese cabbage to Cd stress.
Question_658.Question: What was the main factor influencing the hydroxyl radical scavenging capacity in Chinese cabbage?
Question_658.Source: T1, T2, T4, and T5 treatments significantly increased the hydroxyl radical scavenging capacity of Chinese cabbage leaf and petiole cells.

Question_659.Context: The study investigated the effects of passivators on the antioxidant defense system of Chinese cabbage.
Question_659.Question: Which factor had the greatest direct effect on GSH content in Chinese cabbage?
Question_659.Source: The direct effects on the GSH content in the leaf and petiole cells were greatest for soluble protein content.

Question_660.Context: The study examined the impact of passivators on the physiological and biochemical mechanisms of Cd toxicity reduction in Chinese cabbage.
Question_660.Question: What was the main factor influencing the reduction of oxidative stress in Chinese cabbage?
Question_660.B: Reduction of reactive oxygen species production
Question_660.Source: The application of composite passivator treatments was able to reduce the oxidative stress response of Chinese cabbage by reducing the content of reactive oxygen species.

Question_661.Context: The paper discusses the catalase-like properties of graphene/nano-platinum composites and their application in a colorimetric sensing method. The detection range of Ag+ is mentioned.

Question_669.Source: Graphene oxide/platinum nanoparticles have a strong characteristic peak at 267 nm in addition to 231 nm.

Question_670.B: Reaches a maximum and then decreases

Question_671.Source: Of the examined CsOMTs, CsOMT16 catalyzed the regiospecific 3’‑O‑methylation of flavonoids to the respective 3’‑methoxyflavonoids.

Question_674.Question: Which flavonoid substrate was almost consumed within 2 hours by the E. coli cells transformed with CsOMT16?

Question_675.Source: Chrysoeriol and isorhamnetin exhibit anti-microbial activities against bacteria and fungi.

Question_679.Context: The study focused on the biochemical properties of CsOMT16 and its role in the formation of methoxyflavonoids.

Question_679.Source: The phylogenetic relationships with other functional OMTs and the conservation of the signature motifs suggest that CsOMT16 is a putative candidate of FOMTs in orange.

Question_681.Context: The study investigated the influence of light stress on astaxanthin production in Haematococcus pluvialis during nitrogen starvation.

Question_681.Source: A minimum initial MRPA of 7000 ± 500 µmolhν kgx −1 s−1 was found necessary to trigger large accumulation of astaxanthin in Haematococcus pluvialis cells during nitrogen starvation conditions.

Question_691.Context: Surface roughness plays a crucial role in the mechanical properties of 3D-printed dental implants.
Question_691.Question: How does the arithmetic mean deviation of the assessed profile change with the diameter of the 3D-printed dental implants?

Question_741.Context: The concept of 'macrocyclic cavity' is discussed in relation to the ligand H4DOTA and its coordination with metal ions.
Question_741.Question: What is the key parameter to ensure the high-yield formation of stable coordination metal-DOTA complex?
Question_741.Source: It Is hypothesized that a close matching between the size of the macrocyclic cavity and that of the metallic ion is a key parameter to ensure the high-yield formation of stable coordination metal-DOTA complex.

Question_742.Context: The text discusses the model of 'macrocyclic cavity' in relation to the design of radiopharmaceuticals.
Question_742.Question: What is the model of 'macrocyclic cavity' primarily used to explain?
Question_742.C: The affinity of macrocyclic ligands for alkali metal ions
Question_742.Source: The notion of ‘macrocyclic cavity’ has become popular after Pedersen’s discovery of crown ethers in 1967 and has been used as a key theoretical hypothesis to explain the strong affinity of this class of macrocyclic ligands for alkali metal ions.

Question_743.Context: The text discusses the concept of 'macrocyclic chelate effect' in relation to metal complexes.
Question_743.Question: What does the 'macrocyclic chelate effect' refer to?
Question_743.Source: The ‘macrocyclic chelate effect’ refers to the increase in thermodynamic stabilization of the metal complex when n monodentate ligands are replaced by a macrocyclic ligand containing the same n coordinating atoms connected in a ring.

Question_744.Context: The text discusses the application of Euclidean geometry to analyze the concept of 'macrocyclic cavity'.
Question_744.Question: What does the geometrical analysis reveal about the hypothetical 'macrocyclic cavity'?
Question_744.B: It is necessary for stable coordination complexes
Question_744.C: It does not have physical reality
Question_744.D: It is essential for radiometal binding
Question_744.Source: revealed that this conceptual entity has no physical reality and, therefore, cannot be considered a meaningful description of a stable structural arrangement for metallic radiopharmaceuticals.

Question_745.Context: The text discusses the structural arrangement of metal-DOTA complexes.
Question_745.Question: What determines the observed chemical behavior in metal-DOTA complexes?
Question_745.C: Electronic properties of the metal ion
Question_745.Source: it is the electronic configuration of the metal ion and the energy distribution and symmetry of molecular orbitals that shape the structure of a coordination compound.

Question_746.Context: The text discusses the structural data of DOTA complexes with various metals.
Question_746.Question: What is the parameter Δ used to measure in DOTA complexes?
Question_746.B: Displacement of the metal ion out of the N4 plane
Question_746.Source: The parameter Δ is a measure of the displacement of the metal ion out of the N4 plane and, hence, a measurable physical quantity that unequivocally demonstrates that the concept of the DOTA ‘macrocyclic cavity’ is another glaringly obvious example of misconception in science.

Question_747.Context: The text discusses the structural features of metal-DOTA complexes.
Question_747.Question: What is the observed value of Δ in DOTA metal complexes?
Question_747.Source: There are no examples of DOTA metal complexes with a zero value of Δ.

Question_748.Context: The text discusses the formation of chemical bonds in metal-DOTA complexes.
Question_748.Question: What primarily governs the formation of chemical bonds in metal-DOTA complexes?
Question_748.Source: Ultimately, electronic factors dictate the spatial arrangement of the ligands around the metallic center, thus controlling the final geometry of a metal complex.

Question_749.Context: The text discusses the design of metallic radiopharmaceuticals based on the concept of 'macrocyclic cavity'.
Question_749.Question: What undergoes a rearrangement to meet the electronic requirements of the metal in DOTA complexes?
Question_749.Source: it is the DOTA ligand that undergoes a rearrangement to meet the electronic requirements of the metal.

Question_750.Context: The text discusses the stability of radiopharmaceuticals containing the DOTA ligand.
Question_750.Question: What is not scientifically justified according to the text in relation to the concept of 'macrocyclic cavity'?
Question_750.D: Use of the cavity in radiopharmaceutical design
Question_750.Source: it is not scientifically justified to assume that in complexes with the DOTA ligand it is the metal that must adapt to the conformation of the hypothetical macrocyclic cavity.

Question_767.Context: The paper discusses the applications of high undercutting rate in NH2OH-added NaOH.
Question_767.Question: Why is high undercutting rate beneficial in the fabrication of MEMS components?
Question_767.Source: High etch rate is beneficial to decrease the etching time and hence the higher throughput, which is inevitable for industrial application to reduce the product cost.

Question_768.Context: The paper discusses the effect of etchant age on the etching characteristics.
Question_768.Question: Why is it recommended to use NH2OH-added NaOH immediately after its preparation?
Question_768.D: To take advantage of higher etch rate and undercutting
Question_768.Source: Hence, it is recommended that the NH2OH-added NaOH must be used after its preparation to take the advantage of higher etch rate and undercutting.

Question_769.Context: The paper discusses the surface roughness in pure and NH2OH-added NaOH.
Question_769.Question: What is the surface roughness at the microscopic scale attributed to in wet etching?
Question_769.A: Formation of pyramids or hillocks on the surface
Question_769.B: Formation of a hydrogen bubble during etching
Question_769.C: Deposition of etching by-products on the surface
Question_769.Source: The surface roughness at the microscopic scale occurs due to the non-uniform removal of atoms from the surface or lattice defects which are present on the surface and extend into the bulk crystal.

Question_770.Context: The paper discusses the effect of etchant age on the surface roughness.
Question_770.Question: What happens to the surface roughness with the etchant age?
Question_770.Source: As the etched surface morphology depends on various parameters and can be influenced by any kinds of surface contamination on the silicon surface during etching. However, we can claim from the results that the etched surface roughness is not deteriorated with etchant age.

Question_771.Context: The paper discusses the enzymatic conversion of CO2 to CO using CODH enzymes.
Question_771.Question: What is the primary advantage of using biocatalysts like CODH enzymes for CO2 reduction?
Question_771.Source: Comparing all known natural CO2 fixation pathways, the WL pathway is the most energy efficient by consuming only one ATP.

Question_772.Context: The paper mentions the use of CODH enzymes in electrochemical applications.
Question_772.Question: What is the main challenge in utilizing CODH enzymes in electrocatalysis?
Question_772.Source: The main challenges for the utilization of CODH enzymes in electrocatalysis are their immobilization on the electrode surface and their stability related to either leaching or a low tolerance towards O2.

Question_773.Context: The paper discusses the electrochemical mechanisms involved in utilizing CODH enzymes.
Question_773.Question: What is the preferred electronic communication pathway between the enzyme and the electrode in electrocatalysis?
Question_773.Source: The electronic communication pathway generally considered as the most favorable between enzyme and electrode is the direct electron transfer (DET) via immediate contact of the biomolecule to the solid surface.

Question_774.Context: The paper discusses the electrochemical integration of CODH enzymes in CO2 reduction.
Question_774.Question: What is the primary advantage of using CODH enzymes in CO2 reduction?
Question_774.A: Low overpotential in catalyzing CO2 reduction
Question_774.Source: The electrochemical techniques introduced within this review demonstrate how promising CODH enzymes can be for industrial applications. These studies mainly apply CODHs from already cultured microbial strains for CO2 reduction on electrodes.

Question_775.Context: The paper discusses the use of CODH enzymes in photoelectrochemical systems.
Question_775.Question: What is the main challenge in achieving high turnover frequencies (TOF) in CODH-based photoreduction applications?
Question_775.Source: The enzymes’ TOF in all photoreduction applications is always significantly lower than their inherent activities, which is attributed to a combination of distinct factors: absorption of photons and delivery of charge carriers, recombination of carriers, electron transfer issues, CODH leaching, or enzyme deactivation by O2.

Question_776.Context: The paper discusses the utilization of CODH enzymes in anaerobic CO-coupled metabolisms.
Question_776.Question: What is the primary function of the WL pathway in acetogens?
Question_776.Source: They use the WL pathway not only for the fixation of CO2 according to Eq. 2, but also for redox balancing.

Question_777.Context: The paper discusses the CO-coupled methanogenic metabolism.
Question_777.Question: What is the primary energy source for methanogens in reducing CO2 to methane?
Question_777.Source: The majority of methanogens reduce CO2 to methane and use H2 as the electron donor.

Question_778.Context: The paper discusses the electrochemical applications of CODH enzymes.
Question_778.Question: What is the main challenge in utilizing CODH enzymes in electrocatalysis?
Question_778.Source: The main challenges for the utilization of CODH enzymes in electrocatalysis are their immobilization on the electrode surface and their stability related to either leaching or a low tolerance towards O2.

Question_779.Context: The paper discusses the CO-coupled methanogenic metabolism.
Question_779.Question: What is the primary end product of the CO2 reduction process in methanogens?
Question_779.Source: The majority of methanogens reduce CO2 to methane and use H2 as the electron donor.

Question_780.Context: The paper discusses the CO-coupled methanogenic metabolism.
Question_780.Question: What is the primary challenge in utilizing CO as an energy source for methanogens?
Question_780.Source: This might be caused by the toxic nature of CO as well as that CO-metabolism moves easier towards CH4 alternative products.

Question_781.Context: The study aimed to explore the efficacy of targeted alpha therapy (TAT) in treating neuroendocrine tumors (NETs) using a specific radiolabeled peptide.

Question_781.B: 56.6% intact radiopeptide at 24 h in PBS and 81.0% intact radiopeptide at 24 h in mouse serum
Question_781.C: 95% intact radiopeptide at 24 h in PBS and 94% intact radiopeptide at 24 h in mouse serum
Question_781.D: 81% intact radiopeptide at 24 h in PBS and 81% intact radiopeptide at 24 h in mouse serum
Question_781.Source: Stability studies were performed, showing [225Ac]Ac-DOTA-JR11 had 77% intact radiopeptide at 24 h in PBS and ~81% intact radiopeptide at 24 h in mouse serum.

Question_782.Context: The study investigated the binding affinity of DOTA-JR11 to somatostatin receptor 2 (SSTR2) after complexation with different nuclides.
Question_782.Question: How did the binding affinity of natLa-DOTA-JR11 and natLu-DOTA-JR11 compare to DOTA-JR11 in competitive binding assays?

Question_782.B: natLa-DOTA-JR11 showed higher binding affinity than DOTA-JR11, while natLu-DOTA-JR11 showed lower binding affinity

Question_782.D: natLa-DOTA-JR11 and natLu-DOTA-JR11 showed no binding affinity to SSTR2

Question_789.Source: The absorbed dose to the spleen was 76.4 mGy for [225Ac]Ac-DOTA-JR11 and 8.4 mGy for [177Lu]Lu-DOTA-JR11.

Question_791.Context: The paper discusses the use of multi-junction tandem solar cells to achieve high efficiency in photovoltaics.
Question_791.Question: What is one of the main challenges with tandem solar cells?
Question_791.C: Difficulty in achieving current matching between subcells
Question_791.Source: Due to the numerous functional layers compared to the single junction cell, the probability of photogenerated carrier losses at the interface is high, thus interfacial modification at all interfaces should be a prerequisite to secure high efficiency as well as stability.

Question_792.Context: The paper discusses the concept and structure of tandem solar cells, including the classification based on the direction of charge carrier collection.
Question_792.Question: How are perovskite solar cells classified based on the direction of charge carrier collection?
Question_792.Source: The perovskite solar cells can be classified based on the direction of charge carrier collection into two types: n-i-p (normal) and p-i-n (inverted).

Question_793.Context: The paper discusses the strategies for improving charge-carrier dynamics in perovskite-based tandem cells.
Question_793.Question: What is crucial for efficient charge collection in perovskite materials?
Question_793.A: Formation of a built-in electric field at the perovskite/CTL interface
Question_793.B: High concentration of defects in the perovskite layer
Question_793.D: Low conductivity of the charge transport layer
Question_793.Source: For efficient charge collection, the formation of the built-in electric field at the perovskite/CTL interface and enhanced conductivity of the CTL are crucial.

Question_794.Context: The paper discusses the roles of interface engineering in tandem solar cells.
Question_794.Question: What is one of the functions of interface engineering in perovskite-based tandem cells?
Question_794.A: Reducing the bandgap of the perovskite material
Question_794.C: Increasing the number of functional layers
Question_794.D: Introducing defects in the bulk materials
Question_794.Source: Interface engineering plays a key role in (1) defect passivation, (2) improving charge-carrier dynamics, (3) band alignment, and (4) suppressing ion migration at the interfaces.

Question_795.Context: The paper discusses the concept of defect passivation in perovskite-based tandem cells.
Question_795.Question: What type of defects can induce deep-level traps in perovskite materials?
Question_795.Source: While vacancies and interstitials dominantly exhibit shallow transition energy levels, antisite defects induce deep-level traps which are more detrimental defects than shallow traps.

Question_796.Context: The paper discusses the morphology control of bottom cells in perovskite-based tandem cells.
Question_796.Question: What is an effective strategy for morphology control of chalcogenide thin film solar cells?
Question_796.C: Adding more layers to the bottom cell
Question_796.Source: For chalcogenide thin film solar cells, surface flattening of the bottom cell is an effective strategy for morphology control.

Question_797.Context: The paper discusses the importance of the top electrode in perovskite-based tandem cells.
Question_797.Question: What is essential for the top electrode in perovskite-based tandem cells?
Question_797.C: Protection of the perovskite layer from sputtering damage
Question_797.Source: Additionally, it is essential to protect a perovskite layer from sputtering damage during the deposition of the top electrode.

Question_798.Context: The paper discusses the challenges in the fabrication process of 2-T tandem solar cells.
Question_798.Question: What is a challenge in the fabrication process of 2-T tandem solar cells?
Question_798.B: Difficulty in achieving current matching between subcells
Question_798.D: Low efficiency compared to 4-T tandem cells
Question_798.Source: However, the fabrication process of the 2-T TSC is tricky due to single substrate and current matching between subcells.

Question_799.Context: The paper discusses the use of tunnel junctions in tandem solar cells.
Question_799.Question: What is the function of a tunnel junction in tandem solar cells?
Question_799.B: Protection of the bottom cell during the top cell process
Question_799.C: Reducing optical losses and shunt resistance
Question_799.D: Increasing the thickness of the perovskite layer
Question_799.Source: Using a tunnel junction, optical losses and shunt resistance can be reduced, leading to the increase of the bottom cell photocurrent by more than 1 mA cm–2.

Question_800.Context: The paper discusses the strategies for improving charge-carrier dynamics in perovskite-based tandem cells.
Question_800.Question: What is crucial for efficient charge collection in perovskite materials?
Question_800.A: Formation of a built-in electric field at the perovskite/CTL interface
Question_800.B: High concentration of defects in the perovskite layer
Question_800.D: Low conductivity of the charge transport layer
Question_800.Source: For efficient charge collection, the formation of the built-in electric field at the perovskite/CTL interface and enhanced conductivity of the CTL are crucial.

Question_801.Context: The study investigated the effects of microplastics (MP), food waste (FW), and biochar on soil properties and lettuce growth. The application of FW negatively affected lettuce growth.
Question_801.Question: How did the application of food waste (FW) impact lettuce growth in the study?
Question_801.Source: FW-5 showed significant reductions (p < 0.05) in the number of leaves (36.9%), shoot dry weight (56.7%), root fresh weight (51.8%), and root dry weight (64.5%) compared with the control.

Question_802.Context: The study examined the effects of microplastics (MP), food waste (FW), and biochar on soil properties and lettuce growth. The application of FW and its coexistence with MPs significantly reduced bacterial richness and diversity.
Question_802.Question: How did the application of food waste (FW) and its coexistence with microplastics (MPs) affect soil bacterial richness and diversity?
Question_802.Source: The application of FW and its coexistence with MPs significantly decreased (p < 0.05) the Chao 1 index by 47.5% (FW-5) and 49.5% (MP + FW), as well as the Shannon index by 10.8% (FW-5) and 10.8% (MP + FW).

Question_803.Context: The study focused on the effects of microplastics (MP), food waste (FW), and biochar on soil properties and lettuce growth. The application of biochar did not significantly impact soil enzyme activity.
Question_803.Question: What was the impact of biochar application on soil enzyme activity in the study?
Question_803.D: No significant impact on enzyme activity
Question_803.Source: Although the application of biochar did not show a significant impact on the FDAase activity, the coexistence of MP and biochar (MP + BC) significantly decreased (p < 0.05) FDAase activity by 46.2%.

Question_804.Context: The study investigated the individual and combined effects of microplastics (MP), food waste (FW), and biochar on soil properties and lettuce growth. The application of MPs did not significantly affect soil pH.
Question_804.Question: What was the impact of microplastics (MP) application on soil pH in the study?
Question_804.C: No significant impact on soil pH
Question_804.Source: The application of MPs did not affect the soil pH in either the incubated or cultivated soils.

Question_805.Context: The study focused on the effects of microplastics (MP), food waste (FW), and biochar on soil properties and lettuce growth. The application of FW increased soil electrical conductivity.
Question_805.Question: How did the application of food waste (FW) impact soil electrical conductivity in the study?
Question_805.C: No significant impact on soil electrical conductivity
Question_805.Source: The application of FW increased soil EC from 0.18 dS m−1 (control) to 1.74 dS m−1 (FW-5) and 2.04 dS m−1 (MP + FW) in the incubated soils.

Question_806.Context: The study examined the effects of microplastics (MP), food waste (FW), and biochar on soil properties and lettuce growth. The application of biochar increased soil pH.
Question_806.Question: What was the impact of biochar application on soil pH in the study?
Question_806.C: No significant impact on soil pH
Question_806.Source: The soil pH significantly increased (p < 0.05) in the BC-5 and MP + BC treatments in both incubated and lettuce-cultivated soils compared to the control and MP-1 treatments.

Question_807.Context: The study focused on the effects of microplastics (MP), food waste (FW), and biochar on soil properties and lettuce growth. The application of MPs did not significantly affect soil nitrate and ammonium content.
Question_807.Question: What was the impact of microplastics (MP) application on soil nitrate and ammonium content in the study?
Question_807.C: No significant impact on nitrate and ammonium content
Question_807.Source: The application of MP did not have significant impacts on soil NO3 −-N, NH4 +-N, available P, and TEC contents compared to the controls in both incubated and cultivated soils.

Question_808.Context: The study investigated the individual and combined effects of microplastics (MP), food waste (FW), and biochar on soil properties and lettuce growth. The application of FW and its coexistence with MPs significantly increased available phosphorus content.
Question_808.Question: How did the application of food waste (FW) and its coexistence with microplastics (MPs) impact available phosphorus content in the study?
Question_808.C: No significant impact on available phosphorus content
Question_808.Source: The highest available P contents were observed in the FW-5 (88.4 mg kg−1) and MP + FW (67.9 mg kg−1) treatments in incubated soils.

Question_809.Context: The study examined the effects of microplastics (MP), food waste (FW), and biochar on soil properties and lettuce growth. The application of biochar and its coexistence with MPs did not significantly impact soil total carbon and total nitrogen content.
Question_809.Question: What was the impact of biochar application on soil total carbon and total nitrogen content in the study?
Question_809.A: Decreased total carbon and total nitrogen content
Question_809.B: Increased total carbon and total nitrogen content
Question_809.C: No significant impact on total carbon and total nitrogen content
Question_809.Source: The application of biochar did not have a significant impact on the TN content in soils. However, the application of FW, biochar, and their co-application with MPs significantly increased TN in the incubated soil.

Question_810.Context: The study focused on the effects of microplastics (MP), food waste (FW), and biochar on soil properties and lettuce growth. The coexistence of MPs with food waste (FW) or biochar had limited effects on soil properties and lettuce growth.
Question_810.Question: What was the overall impact of the coexistence of microplastics (MPs) with food waste (FW) or biochar on soil properties and lettuce growth in the study?
Question_810.A: Significantly improved soil properties and lettuce growth
Question_810.B: Negatively affected soil properties and lettuce growth
Question_810.C: Had limited effects on soil properties and lettuce growth
Question_810.Source: Overall, the coexistence of MPs with FW or biochar had limited effects on soil properties and lettuce growth, with FW and biochar serving as the primary factors in modifying soil–plant systems.

Question_811.Context: The study focused on the characterization of triterpene saponins in Hedera nepalensis using UHPLC-Q-TOF-MS/MS method.
Question_811.Question: What is the main purpose of the study?
Question_811.A: To investigate the antibacterial properties of H. nepalensis
Question_811.B: To analyze the chemical constituents of H. nepalensis leaves using a specific method
Question_811.C: To study the economic importance of the Hedera genus
Question_811.D: To explore the antioxidant activities of H. nepalensis
Question_811.Source: The aim of the present study is to characterize the chemical constituents (especially triterpene saponins) of H. nepalensis leaves planted in Vietnam applying UHPLC‐Q‐TOF‐MS/MS technique.

Question_812.Context: The study identified 21 triterpene saponins in H. nepalensis.
Question_812.Question: How many triterpene saponins were elucidated in the study?
Question_812.Source: Forty-five phytochemicals including 21 triterpene saponins were characterized and eight structures have not been reported yet.

Question_813.Context: The study provided a detailed analysis of the chemical structures of triterpene saponins in H. nepalensis.
Question_813.Question: What method was primarily used to characterize the chemical structures?
Question_813.Source: Applying UHPLC‐Q‐TOF‐MS/MS method, the characterization of triterpene saponins structural information in H. nepalensis was successfully analyzed in positive and negative modes.

Question_814.Context: The study mentioned the identification of standard compounds for comparison.
Question_814.Question: Which two standard compounds were examined to clarify the MS fragmentation patterns of triterpene saponins?
Question_814.Source: Two standard compounds, α-hederin and hederacoside C, were examined by UHPLC-Q-TOF-MS/MS in order to clarify the MS fragmentation patterns of triterpene saponins.

Question_815.Context: The study discussed the differentiation of aglycones using positive ionization mode.
Question_815.Question: What are the characteristic ions for hederagenin, oleanolic acid, 30-norhederagenin, and akebonic acid under positive ESI mode?
Question_815.Source: Under the positive ESI mode, hederagenin, oleanolic acid, 30-norhederagenin, and akebonic acid showed the characteristic ion [M + H]+ at m/z 473.3631, 457.3682, 457.3318, and 441.3369, respectively.

Question_816.Context: The study provided insights into the sugar linkages of triterpene saponins.
Question_816.Question: What is the characteristic fragment ion for the loss of glucopyranosyl (Glc) in the sugar chains?
Question_816.Source: The sugar chains of triterpenoid saponins generally substitute at C‐3 and/or C‐28 position(s) of an aglycone. In the positive ESI mode, based on the characteristic fragment ions, the composition of sugar chains can be deduced as follows: the loss of glucopyranosyl (Glc) is 162 Da.

Question_817.Context: The study discussed the identification of known and new chemical structures.
Question_817.Question: What was the total number of triterpenoid saponins identified in Shizhu ginseng in 2016?
Question_817.Source: In 2016, 31 saponins in Shizhu ginseng were identified applying UHPLC‐Q‐TOF‐MS/MS.

Question_818.Context: The study highlighted the successful dereplication of Pulsatilla chinensis using UHPLC-Q-TOF-MS/MS.
Question_818.Question: How many triterpenoid saponins were successfully identified in Pulsatilla chinensis in 2018?
Question_818.Source: In 2018, UHPLC‐Q‐TOF‐MS/MS guided dereplication of Pulsatilla chinensis was successfully identified a total of 22 triterpenoid saponins with four aglycone skeletons.

Question_819.Context: The study mentioned the screening of bioactivities of H. nepalensis extracts.
Question_819.Question: What bioactivities were screened for in the methanolic extracts of H. nepalensis?
Question_819.Source: In addition, H. nepalensis was shown to contain various active compounds including saponins, affording antitumor, antioxidant, and antidiabetic activities.

Question_820.Context: The study aimed to lay a foundation for future drug discovery from H. nepalensis.
Question_820.Question: What was the primary goal of the study regarding future drug discovery?
Question_820.A: To identify novel chemical structures for drug development
Question_820.B: To investigate the economic importance of H. nepalensis
Question_820.C: To study the bioactivities of H. nepalensis extracts
Question_820.D: To analyze the phytochemicals of H. nepalensis leaves
Question_820.Source: The results of this preliminary work can assist in clarifying the chemical compositions of H. nepalensis and accelerating the new drug discovery from this valuable species.

Question_821.Context: Information about SiFA chemistry and its application in radiotracer production.
Question_821.Question: What is the main advantage of SiFA chemistry in radiotracer production?
Question_821.Source: The SiFA radiochemistry has successfully made its entry into clinical radiotracer application demonstrating a high tracer production reliability, a lack of adverse patient reaction after injection and an unprecedented cost efficiency for large batch production.

Question_822.Context: Details about the production of SiFA radiotracers.
Question_822.Question: What is the purpose of the elution cocktail in the automated synthesis of SiFA radiotracers?
Question_822.Source: The elution cocktail consists of a K222/KOH complex, which has to be prepared in advance by lyophilisation of respective aqueous solutions to dryness. 50 nmol precursor and oxalic acid, required to neutralize the amount of base, is pre-filled in the reactor before elution.

Question_823.Context: Information about the automated synthesis of [18F]SiTATE.
Question_823.Question: What is the advantage of the cartridge-based drying method in the synthesis of [18F]SiTATE?
Question_823.Source: The advantage of this method lies in a significant reduction of hardware complexity and time-consuming intermediary steps prior to labeling. By this, losses of radioactivity due to radioactive decay and overall complexity are minimized.

Question_824.Context: Details about the automated synthesis of [18F]Ga-rhPSMA-7/-7.3.
Question_824.Question: What is the purpose of using an Oasis HLB cartridge in the synthesis of [18F]Ga-rhPSMA-7/-7.3?
Question_824.Source: The purification is performed using an Oasis HLB cartridge, which revealed a higher extraction efficiency compared to SepPak C18 materials.

Question_825.Context: Information about the quality control of SiFA radiopharmaceuticals.
Question_825.Question: How is the radiochemical purity of SiFA radiopharmaceuticals determined?
Question_825.Source: The radiochemical purity and identity of the products is determined by ultra- or high-performance liquid chromatography (UPLC/HPLC) with a suitable radioactivity and UV detector.

Question_826.Question: What is added to [18F]SiTATE to prevent radiolytic degradation?
Question_826.Source: It is recommended to adjust the pH of the formulation buffer to 6 by the addition of phosphoric acid. Under basic conditions, partial hydrolysis and a release of [18F]fluoride is found over time. A slightly acidic pH in the final formulation and the addition of ascorbic acid as stabilizer effectively prevents radiolytic and hydrolytic degradation.

Question_827.Context: Information about SiFA chemistry and its application in radiotracer production.
Question_827.Question: What is the main challenge encountered in SiFA automation?
Question_827.Source: Most problems encountered using SiFA chemistry can be attributed to the eluent cocktail. Aqueous solutions of KOH and K222 are mixed at the desired ratio and lyophilized to dryness.

Question_828.Context: Details about the automated synthesis of [18F]SiTATE.
Question_828.Question: What is the purpose of the K222/KOH complex in the synthesis of [18F]SiTATE?
Question_828.Source: The elution cocktail consists of a K222/KOH complex, which has to be prepared in advance by lyophilisation of respective aqueous solutions to dryness. 50 nmol precursor and oxalic acid, required to neutralize the amount of base, is pre-filled in the reactor before elution.

Question_829.Context: Information about SiFA chemistry and its application in radiotracer production.
Question_829.Question: What is the advantage of SiFA chemistry in radiotracer production?
Question_829.Source: The SiFA radiochemistry has successfully made its entry into clinical radiotracer application demonstrating a high tracer production reliability, a lack of adverse patient reaction after injection and an unprecedented cost efficiency for large batch production.

Question_830.Context: Details about the automated synthesis of [18F]Ga-rhPSMA-7/-7.3.
Question_830.Question: What is the purpose of using an Oasis HLB cartridge in the synthesis of [18F]Ga-rhPSMA-7/-7.3?
Question_830.Source: The purification is performed using an Oasis HLB cartridge, which revealed a higher extraction efficiency compared to SepPak C18 materials.

Question_831.Context: Understanding the endocytosis process of internalized nanomedicines through membrane biomarker is crucial for the development of molecular-specific nanomedicines.
Question_831.Question: What is the significance of metalloproteases in the context of cancer cell metastasis?
Question_831.A: They are not involved in cancer cell metastasis.
Question_831.B: They are important markers during the metastasis of cancer cells.
Question_831.C: They have no impact on cancer cell metastasis.
Question_831.D: They are only relevant in non-cancerous cells.

Question_921.Context: In a study on epoxy matrix composites filled with graphite particulates, what effect was observed on the tensile strength of the composite with an increase in graphite content?
Question_921.Question: What effect was observed on the tensile strength of the composite with an increase in graphite content?
Question_921.C: Initial increase followed by a decline
Question_921.Source: The results indicate that the addition of graphite particles significantly affects the mechanical properties of the composite. Tensile strength decreases with an increase in graphite content, with a 1wt% addition resulting in a 56% reduction in tensile strength.

Question_922.Context: What was the observed trend in flexural strength of the graphite/epoxy composites compared to the neat epoxy?
Question_922.Question: What was the observed trend in flexural strength of the graphite/epoxy composites compared to the neat epoxy?
Question_922.C: Initial increase followed by a decline
Question_922.Source: Flexural strength, on the other hand, is improved with the addition of graphite particles, although not in a linear manner. The composite with 0.1wt% graphite exhibits the highest flexural strength.

Question_923.Context: What was the impact of increasing graphite content on the hardness values of the composites?
Question_923.Question: What was the impact of increasing graphite content on the hardness values of the composites?
Question_923.C: Initial increase followed by a decline
Question_923.Source: Hardness and impact values also show improvement with higher graphite content.

Question_924.Context: How did the wear rate vary with an increase in graphite content in the epoxy composites?
Question_924.Question: How did the wear rate vary with an increase in graphite content in the epoxy composites?
Question_924.C: Initial increase followed by a decline
Question_924.Source: The experimental results indicate that the wear rate decreases with an increase in graphite content.

Question_925.Context: What was the observed trend in the friction coefficient with an increase in graphite content and applied load?
Question_925.Question: What was the observed trend in the friction coefficient with an increase in graphite content and applied load?
Question_925.C: Initial increase followed by a decline
Question_925.Source: The specimens with 1wt% graphite content consistently exhibited the lowest coefficient of friction among all applied loads and sliding speeds.

Question_926.Context: How did the wear rate vary with an increase in sliding speed in the epoxy composites?
Question_926.Question: How did the wear rate vary with an increase in sliding speed in the epoxy composites?
Question_926.C: Initial increase followed by a decline
Question_926.Source: An interesting trend observed in this study is the reduction of wear rate with an increase in sliding speed.

Question_927.Context: What was the observed failure mode in the layered composites?
Question_927.Question: What was the observed failure mode in the layered composites?
Question_927.Source: The failure mode observed in the layered specimens was delamination, characterized by interlayer debonding and changes in the crack propagation direction between the layers.

Question_928.Context: What was the impact of increasing graphite content on the impact strength of the composites?
Question_928.Question: What was the impact of increasing graphite content on the impact strength of the composites?
Question_928.C: Initial increase followed by a decline
Question_928.Source: Regarding impact strength, the incorporation of 1wt% graphite resulted in a 29% increase in impact value compared to the neat epoxy.

Question_929.Context: How did the friction coefficient change with an increase in graphite content and applied load?
Question_929.Question: How did the friction coefficient change with an increase in graphite content and applied load?
Question_929.C: Initial increase followed by a decline
Question_929.Source: The reduction in the coefficient of friction was most significant when the applied load was changed. While the sliding speed had a relatively minor effect on the coefficient of friction of the composites, a noticeable effect was observed with higher applied loads.

Question_930.Context: What was the observed trend in wear rate with an increase in sliding speed in the epoxy composites?
Question_930.Question: What was the observed trend in wear rate with an increase in sliding speed in the epoxy composites?
Question_930.C: Initial increase followed by a decline
Question_930.Source: An interesting trend observed in this study is the reduction of wear rate with an increase in sliding speed.

Question_941.Context: The paper discusses the optical properties of CsPbBr3 nanoplatelets and their anisotropy.
Question_941.Question: What is the main factor that determines the band gap tunability of CsPbBr3 nanoplatelets?
Question_941.Source: The two-dimensional CsPbBr3 nanoplatelets have a quantum well electronic structure with a band gap tunable with sample thicknesses in discreet steps based upon the number of monolayers.

Question_942.Context: The paper discusses the optical properties of CsPbBr3 nanoplatelets and their anisotropy.
Question_942.Question: What is the observed trend in optical anisotropy as the thickness of CsPbBr3 nanoplatelets increases?
Question_942.Source: The thicker (4 ML, 5 ML) NPLs show a progressive decrease in the measured anisotropy and cuboidal CsPbBr3 NCs show small but consistently positive values of anisotropy by all measurements.

Question_943.Context: The paper discusses the optical properties of CsPbBr3 nanoplatelets and their anisotropy.
Question_943.Question: What type of polarization is observed in the emission transitions of CsPbBr3 nanoplatelets at the band edge?
Question_943.Source: The band-edge absorption and emission for ensembles of NPLs exceeds 0.08, approaching the theoretical value of perfect in-plane polarization of 0.1.

Question_944.Context: The paper discusses the optical properties of CsPbBr3 nanoplatelets and their anisotropy.
Question_944.Question: What technique is used to measure the anisotropic optical properties of CsPbBr3 nanoplatelets in solution?
Question_944.Source: A second measurement technique which has been used to measure anisotropy of colloidal nanoparticles is polarized transient absorption spectroscopy.

Question_945.Context: The paper discusses the optical properties of CsPbBr3 nanoplatelets and their anisotropy.
Question_945.Question: What is the main reason for the diminishing anisotropy observed in thicker CsPbBr3 nanoplatelets?
Question_945.Source: The experimental results of this work can be understood as a verification of the calculations of exciton fine structure showing strong in-plane polarization of the thinnest NPLs, with diminishing values at thicker size.

Question_946.Context: The paper discusses the optical properties of CsPbBr3 nanoplatelets and their anisotropy.
Question_946.Question: What is the significance of the observed planar absorption and emission transitions in CsPbBr3 nanoplatelets?
Question_946.Source: Dominant planar emission, albeit confined to the thinnest nanoplatelets, is a valuable attribute for enhanced efficiency of light-emitting devices.

Question_947.Context: The paper discusses the synthesis of CsPbBr3 nanoplatelets.
Question_947.Question: Which materials are used in the room temperature synthesis of CsPbBr3 nanoplatelets?
Question_947.Source: Precursor solutions were prepared by dissolving 32.6 mg Cs2CO3 in 10 mL oleic acid and 36.7 mg PbBr2 in 10 mL toluene with 0.1 mL oleic acid and 0.1 mL oleylamine.

Question_948.Context: The paper discusses the synthesis of CsPbBr3 nanoplatelets.
Question_948.Question: What is the main difference between the room temperature synthesis and hot injection synthesis of CsPbBr3 nanoplatelets?
Question_948.Source: The synthesis for the 458 nm emitting NPLs was modified from this literature. 138 mg of PbBr2, 1 mL of dried oleic acid, and 1 mL of dried oleylamine were loaded into a 25 mL 3-neck flask under anaerobic conditions.

Question_949.Context: The paper discusses the methods used for structural characterization of CsPbBr3 nanoplatelets.
Question_949.Question: Which technique was used for transmission electron microscopy (TEM) analysis of the samples?
Question_949.Source: Transmission electron microscopy (TEM) was performed on the samples using a JEOL 2100F TEM.

Question_950.Context: The paper discusses the results and discussion related to the optical properties of CsPbBr3 nanoplatelets.
Question_950.Question: What is the main conclusion drawn from the optical properties analysis of CsPbBr3 nanoplatelets?
Question_950.A: Thinner nanoplatelets exhibit higher anisotropy than thicker ones
Question_950.C: Cuboidal nanocrystals have isotropic optical transitions
Question_950.D: Exciton fine structure has no impact on anisotropy
Question_950.Source: The results confirm the predictions of exciton fine structure calculations of a strong thickness-dependence of anisotropy, which stands in contrast to other NPL systems.

Question_957.Source: Chrysanthemum oil formula exhibited marked reduction in TNF-α expression compared to the acne-infected mice group.

Question_961.Context: The study focused on optimizing the continuous extrusion process parameters for aluminum alloy (AA 1100) feedstock materials using response surface methodology.

Question_963.Context: The study analyzed the effect of wheel speed and product diameter on yield strength.
Question_963.Question: How does the yield strength vary with changes in wheel speed and product diameter?
Question_963.A: Yield strength decreases with increasing wheel speed and product diameter.
Question_963.B: Yield strength remains constant with changes in wheel speed and product diameter.
Question_963.C: Yield strength increases with increasing wheel speed and product diameter.
Question_963.D: Yield strength initially decreases, becomes minimum, and then increases with further increase in wheel speed and product diameter.
Question_963.Source: The surface plot signifies that the value of yield strength initially decreases, becomes minimum, and then increases with further increase in the values of input process variables.

Question_964.Context: The study investigated the effect of wheel speed and product diameter on % elongation.
Question_964.Question: How does % elongation change with variations in wheel speed and product diameter?
Question_964.A: % elongation decreases with increasing wheel speed and product diameter.
Question_964.B: % elongation remains constant with changes in wheel speed and product diameter.
Question_964.C: % elongation increases with increasing wheel speed and product diameter.
Question_964.D: % elongation initially increases, becomes maximum, and then decreases with further increase in wheel speed and product diameter.
Question_964.Source: The surface plot of % elongation signifies that % elongation of the extruded material increases with the increase in the values of wheel speed and diameter of product and is maximum at a given value of wheel speed and diameter of product and decreases thereafter.

Question_965.Context: The study conducted microstructural analysis of aluminum alloy under different wheel speeds and extrusion ratios.

Question_965.A: Grain size decreased with increasing wheel speed.

Question_1001.Context: Experimental setup for IR irradiation of posAuNP@UCNPs and UCNP-coated posAuNP@UCNPs.
Question_1001.Question: What was the purpose of irradiating posAuNP@UCNPs with 980 nm light?
Question_1001.A: To measure the temperature changes in the nanoparticles.
Question_1001.B: To observe the morphological changes in the nanoparticles.
Question_1001.C: To confirm the formation of vapor nanobubbles.
Question_1001.D: To facilitate intracellular delivery through photoporation.
Question_1001.Source: The occurrence of exotherm is a critical factor for AuNP photoporation because it leads to the formation of vapor nanobubbles (VNBs), which burst and perforate the cell membrane. Therefore, this result confirms that UCNP coating of AuNPs increases the formation of VNBs by increasing the resistive heating losses (RHL) of the AuNPs, ultimately leading to higher UCPPin efficiency.

Question_1002.Context: Characterization of UCNP and posAuNP@UCNPs for photoporation.
Question_1002.Question: What is the significance of the upconversion process in UCNPs?
Question_1002.A: It allows UCNPs to absorb visible light.
Question_1002.B: It converts high-energy visible light to low-energy NIR light.
Question_1002.C: It converts low-energy NIR light to high-energy visible light.
Question_1002.D: It enhances the stability of UCNPs in aqueous solutions.
Question_1002.Source: The Yb3+ ions in the UCNP absorb light at 980 nm, which triggers an anti-Stokes reaction and results in the emission of light at 545 nm (green light). This phenomenon is known as upconversion, and it allows the UCNP to convert low-energy near-infrared light (NIR) to high-energy visible light.

Question_1003.Context: Confirmation of resistive heating losses (RHL) and morphological changes in posAuNP@UCNPs under IR irradiation.
Question_1003.Question: What was the purpose of calculating the resistive heating losses (RHL) in the nanoparticles?
Question_1003.A: To measure the temperature changes in the nanoparticles.
Question_1003.B: To determine the effect of UCNP coating on the electric field.
Question_1003.C: To analyze the distribution of the electric field in the nanoparticles.
Question_1003.D: To evaluate the efficiency of photoporation in the nanoparticles.
Question_1003.Source: The occurrence of exotherm is a critical factor for AuNP photoporation because it leads to the formation of vapor nanobubbles (VNBs), which burst and perforate the cell membrane. Therefore, this result confirms that UCNP coating of AuNPs increases the formation of VNBs by increasing the resistive heating losses (RHL) of the AuNPs, ultimately leading to higher UCPPin efficiency.

Question_1004.Context: Observation of posAuNP@UCNPs localization and confirmation of transient perforation and re-sealing of the plasma membrane in C28/I2 cells under IR irradiation.
Question_1004.Question: What is the main purpose of the time-lapse imaging under IR irradiation?
Question_1004.A: To observe the attachment of nanoparticles to the cell membrane.
Question_1004.B: To confirm the formation of vapor nanobubbles.
Question_1004.C: To measure the intracellular calcium level during PM re-sealing.
Question_1004.D: To visualize the transient perforation and re-sealing of the plasma membrane.
Question_1004.Source: Images were taken for up to 180 cycles every 6.5 s. It was observed that posAuNP@UCNPs were attached to PM and pores were formed, and then PM was re-sealed again. These results confirmed that posAuNP@UCNPs attach to the cell membrane surface and form pores on the membrane surface under NIR irradiation.

Question_1005.Context: Comparison of UCPPin efficiency of posAuNP@UCNPs under different IR conditions in C28/I2 cell suspensions and spheroids.
Question_1005.Question: What was the purpose of analyzing UCPPin efficiency under pulsed IR at different pulse intervals?
Question_1005.A: To determine the optimal dose of posAuNP for UCPPin.
Question_1005.B: To evaluate the effect of different pulse intervals on UCPPin efficiency.
Question_1005.C: To compare the efficiency of UCPPin under continuous and pulsed IR.
Question_1005.D: To measure the intracellular calcium level during PM re-sealing.
Question_1005.Source: The 2 min PI group showed high UCPPin efficiency similar to that of continuous irradiation time of 20 min, but the UCPPin efficiency decreased as the PI increased. At AuNP to UCNP ratios of 1:5 and 1:10, the UCPPin efficiency was high with no significant difference in efficiency between these two ratios; however, since processing a small amount is more appropriate than that of a large amount, the 1:5 ratio was used.

Question_1006.Context: Comparison of therapeutic efficacy between UCPPin and PassT for intracellular delivery of baricitinib in an in vitro model of osteoarthritis.
Question_1006.Question: What was the main finding regarding the delivery of baricitinib into cells using UCPPin compared to PassT?
Question_1006.A: UCPPin resulted in higher cell viability.
Question_1006.B: UCPPin delivered more baricitinib into cells.
Question_1006.C: UCPPin had a lower efficiency in inhibiting STAT phosphorylation.
Question_1006.D: UCPPin caused a higher expression of IL-6 in cells.
Question_1006.Source: Thus, UCPPin would appear to deliver BRN into cells more efficiently than PassT, as evidenced by the level of inhibition of IL-6 expression.

Question_1007.Context: Characterization of posAuNP@UCNPs before and after IR irradiation.

Question_1007.A: The nanoparticles aggregated into larger clusters.
Question_1007.B: The nanoparticles dissociated and remained dispersed.
Question_1007.C: The nanoparticles decreased in size due to heat generation.
Question_1007.D: The nanoparticles increased in size due to photoporation effect.
Question_1007.Source: In the IR 20 min group, the UCNPs had dissociated from the posAuNP@UCNPs and were present in a free state. The change in size was measured by DLS, which showed that the nanoparticles were separate from each other and remained dispersed in a free form until IR 60 min.

Question_1008.Context: Evaluation of UCPPin efficiency under different IR conditions.
Question_1008.Question: What effect did increasing the UCNP ratio have on UCPPin efficiency?
Question_1008.A: Increased UCNP ratio led to decreased UCPPin efficiency.
Question_1008.B: Higher UCNP ratio had no impact on UCPPin efficiency.
Question_1008.C: Higher UCNP ratio resulted in higher UCPPin efficiency.
Question_1008.D: UCNP ratio had no correlation with UCPPin efficiency.
Question_1008.Source: Higher UCPPin efficiencies were observed at posAuNP to UCNP ratios of 1:1, 1:2, 1:5, and 1:10 than at 1:0. The efficiency was particularly high at ratios of 1:5 or greater, indicating that a higher UCNP ratio led to higher UCPPin efficiency.

Question_1009.Context: Comparison of UCPPin efficiency under different IR conditions.
Question_1009.Question: What was the impact of increasing the irradiation time on UCPPin efficiency?
Question_1009.A: Increasing irradiation time decreased UCPPin efficiency.
Question_1009.B: Higher irradiation time had no effect on UCPPin efficiency.
Question_1009.C: Increasing irradiation time improved UCPPin efficiency.
Question_1009.D: Irradiation time was not related to UCPPin efficiency.
Question_1009.Source: As the irradiation time increased, the electromagnetic energy applied to cells accumulated, resulting in increased membrane disruption, dead cells, and higher UCPPin efficiency. The longer the irradiation time, the greater the accumulation of electromagnetic energy applied to the cells, resulting in increased membrane disruption, dead cell, and UCPPin efficiency.

Question_1010.Context: Evaluation of UCPPin efficiency under different IR conditions.

Question_1010.A: To compare UCPPin efficiency between suspended cells and spheroids.
Question_1010.B: To determine the impact of spheroid size on UCPPin efficiency.
Question_1010.C: To evaluate the effectiveness of UCPPin in a 3D cell model.
Question_1010.D: To measure the intracellular calcium level in spheroids.
Question_1010.Source: An experiment was conducted to verify whether the pulsed wave could be applied to cell spheroids. The 1:5 group showed an efficiency of about 30%, indicating high UCPPin efficiency. It is generally known that as osteoarthritis progresses, the expression level of proinflammatory cytokines such as IL-6 increases. Additionally, IL-6 signaling has been reported to be actively involved in osteoarthritis pathology and to be a factor in cartilage degradation. Therefore, in this study, baricitinib (BRN), an inhibitor of STAT1 and 3 phosphorylation, was used as a therapeutic agent to specifically target STAT-IL-6 signaling.

Question_1024.Context: The study investigates the stability of defects at twin interfaces.
Question_1024.Question: What is the proposed mechanism for the decay of large steps along the twin interface?
Question_1024.Source: Simulations suggest that large ledges along the twin boundaries could decay by generating twinning dislocations.

Question_1025.Context: The study discusses the generation of twinning dislocations from ledges on a twin interface.
Question_1025.Question: What is the proposed mechanism for the nucleation of disconnection loops from ledges in the twin interface?
Question_1025.C: Nucleation of steps and edge dislocations
Question_1025.Source: The observed mechanism is the nucleation of disconnection loops from ledges in the twin interface. The generated disconnection loops are composed of a step and of a dislocation, and they help propagating the twin interface.

Question_1026.Context: The study explores the behavior of disclinations at material interfaces.
Question_1026.Question: What is the proposed motion of disclination loops on minimum energy interface planes?

Question_1027.Context: The study discusses the dynamics of twin thickening mediated by the motion of ledges.
Question_1027.Question: What is the mechanism proposed for the thickening of twin domains?
Question_1027.Source: The thickening of twin domains is mediated by the generation of twinning dislocations from ledges present on the twin interface.

Question_1028.Context: The study investigates the stability of defects at twin interfaces.
Question_1028.Question: What is the proposed outcome of the decay of large ledges along the twin boundaries?
Question_1028.Source: Large ledges along the twin boundaries decay by generating twinning dislocations, which are composed of a step and a dislocation, aiding in propagating the twin interface.

Question_1029.Context: The study discusses the application of the model to study the stability of 3-dimensional defects at twin interfaces.
Question_1029.Question: What is the proposed mechanism for the stability and transverse propagation of an isolated � 10¯12 � twin domain?
Question_1029.Source: The stability and transverse propagation of an isolated � 10¯12 � twin domain is modeled by creating twin embryos with disclination loops, leading to the generation of twinning dislocations.

Question_1030.Context: The study discusses the generation of twinning dislocations from ledges on a twin interface.
Question_1030.Question: What is the proposed outcome of the out of plane motion of disclination loops crossing onto Basal/Pyramidal (BP) and Pyramidal/Pyramidal (PP) interfaces?
Question_1030.Source: The out of plane motion of disclination loops crossing onto BP and PP interfaces leads to the generation of dipolar arrangements of square twinning dislocation loops.
