Question_3832.Context: Microplastics were detected in various types of land use. The study used stereo microscopy to analyze the microplastics in the soil samples.
Question_3832.Question: What was the most frequently detected color of microplastics in the soil samples?
Question_3832.Source: Regardless of land use, detected microplastics had a significantly higher proportion of fragments and black color.

Question_3833.Context: The study focused on the distribution of microplastics in different land use types. Fourier transform infrared spectrometer (FT-IR) was used for qualitative analysis of microplastics.
Question_3833.Question: Which material was most frequently detected in soils from roadsides?
Question_3833.Source: In roadside soil, PE and PP were detected.

Question_3834.Context: The study analyzed the distribution characteristics of microplastics by size in different types of land use.
Question_3834.Question: In which type of land use were microplastics larger than 1 mm most prevalent?
Question_3834.Source: The proportion of microplastics larger than 1 mm was the highest in roadside and agricultural land soils.

Question_3835.Context: The study conducted FT-IR analysis to identify microplastics in soils from different land use types.
Question_3835.Question: Which material was not detected in agricultural land soils during the FT-IR analysis?
Question_3835.Source: In agricultural land soils, only small amounts of PET and PU particles were detected.

Question_3836.Context: The study compared the distribution of microplastics in different land use types.
Question_3836.Question: Which color of microplastics was the second most prevalent in agricultural land soils?
Question_3836.Source: White fragments were the second highest after black in roadside, forest, and residential areas, while in parks and agricultural lands, green was the second highest after black.

Question_3837.Context: The study analyzed the distribution of microplastics by shape and color in various types of land use.
Question_3837.Question: Which shape of microplastics was most frequently detected in forest soils?
Question_3837.Source: The distribution by color was 90.2% black, 6.1% white, 2.9% green, 0.4% red, 0.2% blue, 0.1% yellow, and 0.1% transparent.

Question_3838.Context: The study utilized FT-IR analysis to identify microplastics in soils from different land use types.
Question_3838.Question: Which material was most frequently detected in residential area soils?
Question_3838.Source: In residential area soils, PP accounted for the majority of microplastics found.

Question_3839.Context: The study examined the distribution characteristics of microplastics by size in different types of land use.
Question_3839.Question: In which type of land use were microplastics under 300 µm most prevalent?
Question_3839.Source: It is estimated that the size of microplastics decreases and the number of individual pieces increases in forests and parks because there are relatively fewer human activities compared to roadside, residential areas, and agricultural land.

Question_3840.Context: The study focused on the distribution of microplastics in different land use types. Stereo microscopy was used to analyze the microplastics in the soil samples.
Question_3840.Question: Which type of land use had the highest average number of microplastics detected in the soil samples?
Question_3840.Source: Microplastics in the soils from agricultural land and roadside were significantly higher than those in residential areas and parks.

Question_3841.Context: The study compared the distribution of microplastics in different land use types.
Question_3841.Question: Which color of microplastics was the least prevalent in roadside soils?
Question_3841.Source: The distribution by color was 90.2% black, 6.1% white, 2.9% green, 0.4% red, 0.2% blue, 0.1% yellow, and 0.1% transparent.

Question_3842.Context: The study focused on developing biodegradable films based on thermoplastic corn starch and copper particles with antimicrobial capacity. The films were obtained by melt-mixing and thermo-compression. Particles distribution within the matrix and the effects on transparency and mechanical properties were evaluated.
Question_3842.Question: What was the main purpose of developing the biodegradable films in the study?
Question_3842.A: To enhance the color of the films
Question_3842.B: To decrease the tensile strength of the films
Question_3842.C: To inhibit the growth of bacteria
Question_3842.D: To increase the elongation at break of the films
Question_3842.Source: Composites inhibited the growth of Gram+ and Gram- bacteria, demonstrating their antimicrobial capacity.

Question_3843.Context: The study involved the preparation of copper particles by reducing a copper salt solution with hydrazine. The stabilizing agent used was an aqueous starch solution. The particles were coated with silica to improve stability.
Question_3843.Question: What method was used to prepare the copper particles in the study?
Question_3843.Source: Cu particles preparation was carried out by reducing a copper salt solution (CuCl2, 0.05 M) with hydrazine (5% w/v).

Question_3844.Context: The study evaluated the mechanical properties of the films by conducting tensile tests. The stress-strain curves showed that the films were ductile materials. The addition of copper particles at certain concentrations acted as reinforcing agents.
Question_3844.Question: What effect did the addition of copper particles have on the mechanical properties of the films?
Question_3844.Source: Regarding maximum tensile strength, Cu and Si-Cu particles addition at 1 and 5% acted as reinforcing agents increasing the maximum tensile strength.

Question_3845.Context: The study assessed the antimicrobial activity of the composite films against Escherichia coli and Staphylococcus aureus. The films containing copper particles up to 0.75% showed antimicrobial activity against both types of bacteria.
Question_3845.Question: Which microorganisms were used to test the antimicrobial activity of the composite films?
Question_3845.Source: Antimicrobial assays results are shown in Table 1. As it can be observed, TPS/Cu and TPS/Si-Cu samples showed antimicrobial activity against both Gram-positive (S. aureus) and Gram-negative (E. coli) bacteria.

Question_3846.Context: The study evaluated the release of copper particles from the films into a simulant of aqueous foods. The released copper concentrations were measured, and it was found that both naked copper and silica-coated copper particles migrated from the films to the aqueous medium.
Question_3846.Question: What was the purpose of evaluating the copper release from the films?
Question_3846.A: To determine the color change in the films
Question_3846.B: To assess the mechanical properties of the films
Question_3846.C: To evaluate the antimicrobial activity of the films
Question_3846.D: To understand the migration of the antimicrobial agent to the food surface
Question_3846.Source: The use of antimicrobial packaging increases food safety and minimizes the addition of synthetic additives directly to food. Besides, some antimicrobial agents confer unpleasant sensory characteristics to food products and additives incorporation into packaging avoids this issue.

Question_3847.Context: The study investigated the optical properties of the films, including luminosity, color, and transparency. It was observed that the films became less transparent with the addition of copper particles, leading to a reduction in visible light transmission.
Question_3847.Question: What effect did the addition of copper particles have on the transparency of the films?
Question_3847.Source: As it can be observed, copper particles induced a reduction on transparency values of TPS films.

Question_3848.Context: The study characterized the particles used in the films through scanning electron microscopy. The images confirmed the spherical shape of the particles and showed clusters forming. Silica coating was applied to improve stability.
Question_3848.Question: What was the purpose of applying silica coating to the copper particles?
Question_3848.A: To decrease the stability of the particles
Question_3848.C: To change the color of the particles
Question_3848.Source: Silica coating was performed in order to improve Cu particles stability.

Question_3849.Context: The study evaluated the color measurements of the films using a colorimeter. The luminosity decreased with the addition of copper particles, while the a* and b* parameters increased, indicating changes in color.
Question_3849.Question: What parameter decreased with the addition of copper particles in the color measurements of the films?
Question_3849.Source: Luminosity (L*) of TPS films decreased significantly with the addition of Cu and Si-Cu particles.

Question_3850.Context: The study conducted tensile tests on the films to assess their mechanical properties. The stress-strain curves indicated that the films were ductile materials, and the addition of copper particles at certain concentrations affected the maximum tensile strength and elongation at break.
Question_3850.Question: What type of materials were the films characterized as based on the stress-strain curves?
Question_3850.Source: Stress-strain curves of TPS and composites films showed that their mechanical behavior corresponds to ductile materials.

Question_3851.Context: The study assessed the antimicrobial activity of the composite films against Escherichia coli and Staphylococcus aureus. The films containing copper particles up to 0.75% showed antimicrobial activity against both types of bacteria.
Question_3851.Question: Which particles showed a lower migration rate from the films to the aqueous medium?
Question_3851.Source: The fact that copper particles have migrated from TPS films, independently if they are naked or coated, to the aqueous medium could be attributed to the quick water penetration into to the starch-glycerol matrix, allowing the diffusion of the active compounds to the simulant.

Question_3852.Context: The study aimed to evaluate factors influencing soil EC sensor values by monitoring EC under different soil organic matter and water contents.
Question_3852.Question: What is the relationship between soil EC and water content?
Question_3852.Source: Soil EC showed a linear correlation with water content at water content of 10–25% for loam and sandy loam soils and at water content of 10–40% for silty clay loam soil.

Question_3853.Context: The study involved monitoring EC and water content in soil samples with added organic matter.
Question_3853.Question: How did the calibration factor for soil EC change when organic matter was added to the soil?
Question_3853.Source: In comparison to the soil without organic matter, the calibration factor was higher when organic matter was added to the soil.

Question_3854.Context: The study analyzed exchangeable ion contents in soil samples with and without added organic matter.
Question_3854.Question: Which ion content increased when organic matter was added to the soil?
Question_3854.Source: The concentration of exchangeable ions such as K, and Ca in the soil increased when organic matter was added in the soil.

Question_3855.Context: The research involved conducting correlation analyses between EC and organic matter.
Question_3855.Question: What was the correlation between sensor EC values and soil organic matter?
Question_3855.Source: The sensor EC value of sandy loam soil was highly correlated with the ion content in pore water, and the sensor EC value of loam soil was highly correlated with exchangeable ions.

Question_3856.Context: The study utilized PCA to evaluate the relationship between sensor EC values and soil properties.
Question_3856.Question: What did the first principal component show positive correlations with?
Question_3856.Source: The first PC showed positive correlations with sand content, pore water pH, and exchangeable Ca and P.

Question_3857.Context: The study discussed the variability explained by different principal components.
Question_3857.Question: What percentage of total variance was explained by the second principal component?
Question_3857.Source: The second PC accounted for 23.2% of the total variation.

Question_3858.Context: The research highlighted the importance of considering soil texture in interpreting sensor EC values.
Question_3858.Question: Which soil texture showed a high correlation between sensor EC values and ion content in pore water?
Question_3858.Source: The sensor EC value of sandy loam soil was highly correlated with the ion content in pore water.

Question_3859.Context: The study emphasized the impact of organic matter on sensor EC values.
Question_3859.Question: How did organic matter affect the sensor EC values?
Question_3859.Source: The sensor EC value of sandy loam soil was highly correlated with the ion content in pore water, and the sensor EC value of loam soil was highly correlated with exchangeable ions.

Question_3860.Context: The study discussed the relationship between sensor EC values and nutrient levels in soil.
Question_3860.Question: What nutrient content was closely related to sensor EC values?
Question_3860.Source: The sensor EC monitoring values showed a high correlation with the contents of NO3 −, K, S and Ca in the pore water.

Question_3861.Context: The research highlighted the importance of considering organic matter and soil texture in nutrient monitoring.
Question_3861.Question: Why is it important to consider organic matter and soil texture in nutrient monitoring using EC sensors?
Question_3861.Source: Therefore, when monitoring nutrient levels in soil using EC sensor, organic matter and soil texture need to be considered.

Question_3862.Context: The study focuses on the phase-field simulation of dendrite growth during the solidification of an alloy.
Question_3862.Question: What method is effective for improving the computational performance when the diffusion length is significantly larger than the curvature radius of a dendrite tip?
Question_3862.Source: In such cases, the adaptive mesh refinement (AMR) method is effective for improving the computational performance.

Question_3863.Context: The study discusses the use of graphics processing units (GPUs) for parallel computation.
Question_3863.Question: What is a key advantage of using GPUs in phase-field simulations of dendritic solidification?
Question_3863.Source: GPU computing is quite efficient for implementing discretization methods with simple calculation algorithms, such as finite difference or finite volume methods.

Question_3864.Context: The study evaluates the efficiency of dynamic load balancing in multiple-GPU parallel computations.
Question_3864.Question: What is the purpose of dynamic load balancing in domain subdivision for parallel computing?
Question_3864.A: To increase the computational cost per GPU
Question_3864.B: To reduce the number of grid points per GPU
Question_3864.C: To equalize the computational cost per GPU
Question_3864.D: To limit the efficiency of parallel computation
Question_3864.Source: In the parallel GPU computation, we apply dynamic load balancing to parallel computing to equalize the computational cost per GPU.

Question_3865.Context: The study describes the PF model used for simulations.
Question_3865.Question: How is the morphological evolution of dendrites expressed in the PF model?
Question_3865.Source: The morphological evolution of dendrites is expressed by solving the PF equation.

Question_3866.Context: The study discusses the use of an adaptive mesh refinement (AMR) method.
Question_3866.Question: What is the purpose of AMR in resolving problems such as a wide primary arm spacing compared to the curvature radius of a dendrite tip?
Question_3866.B: To reduce the efficiency of computations
Question_3866.D: To limit the number of dendrites
Question_3866.Source: AMR is extremely effective in resolving problems such as a wide primary arm spacing compared to the curvature radius of a dendrite tip.

Question_3867.Context: The study evaluates the AMR refinement condition through single-GPU computations.
Question_3867.Question: What is the maximum refinement level set for evaluating the AMR refinement condition?
Question_3867.Source: The maximum refinement level is set as nmax = 0, 1, 2, 3, 4, and 5.

Question_3868.Context: The study discusses the computational domain subdivision using the slice-grid method.
Question_3868.Question: How are the subdomain boundaries determined in the dynamic load balancing using the slice-grid method?
Question_3868.C: Based on integral multiples of X0
Question_3868.Source: Here, the slide distances of the subdomain boundaries are set as integral multiples of X0.

Question_3869.Context: The study evaluates the performance of dynamic load balancing in multiple-GPU parallel computations.
Question_3869.Question: What is the ratio of the maximum and average number of grid points assigned to 16 GPUs in Case 3?
Question_3869.Source: At t = 3.0 × 106Δt, the ratio of the maximum and average number of grid points assigned to 16 GPUs is approximately 1.84.

Question_3870.Context: The study performs weak scaling tests to evaluate the parallel computation performance.
Question_3870.Question: What is the execution time per 2000 time steps with 256 GPUs compared to 16 GPUs?
Question_3870.Source: As shown in the figure, the execution time with 256 GPUs is only 1.7% longer than that with 16 GPUs.

Question_3871.Context: The study concludes by discussing the efficiency of the developed simulation scheme.
Question_3871.Question: What advantage does the developed scheme offer for simulating the growth of numerous dendrites?
Question_3871.Source: The developed scheme can significantly improve the efficiency of simulations under solidification conditions with a large solute diffusion length and/or large primary arm spacing.

Question_3872.Context: The study isolated an Enterobacter cloacae strain DJ with plant-promoting effects and investigated its adaptation to salinity-alkalinity environments. What was the average diameter of the colonies on the salinity-alkalinity medium after 24 hours of incubation compared to the ADF medium?
Question_3872.Question: What was the average diameter of the colonies on the salinity-alkalinity medium after 24 hours of incubation?
Question_3872.Source: The average diameter of the colonies on the salinity-alkalinity medium after incubation for 24 h was 3.3 cm, and this was significantly higher than the 1.9 cm diameter in ADF medium (p < 0.01).

Question_3873.Context: Comparative proteomic analysis revealed differentially expressed proteins in salinity-alkalinity groups compared to control groups. Which pathway was the top one upregulated in the KEGG enrichment analysis?
Question_3873.Question: What was the top one upregulated pathway in the KEGG enrichment analysis?
Question_3873.Source: The top one upregulated pathway of KEGG enrichment was bacterial chemotaxis, DJ bacteria adapted to salinity-alkalinity environments by upregulating the genes associated with bacterial chemotaxis.

Question_3874.Context: Polyamines putrescine and spermidine were analyzed in the supernatant of DJ bacteria under different conditions. What were the contents of putrescine in the salinity-alkalinity and control groups?
Question_3874.Question: What were the contents of putrescine in the salinity-alkalinity and control groups?
Question_3874.Source: The contents of putrescine in salinity-alkalinity and control groups were 4.73 μg/mL and 3.02 μg/mL, respectively.

Question_3875.Context: The study examined the stem height, number of lateral roots, and fresh weight of cucumber seedlings in different treatment groups. What was the stem height of cucumber seedlings in the DJ treatment groups compared to the control groups?
Question_3875.Question: What was the stem height of cucumber seedlings in the DJ treatment groups?
Question_3875.Source: The stem height, number of lateral roots, and fresh weight of cucumber seedlings in the DJ treatment groups were 6.0 cm, 17 roots, and 0.42 g, respectively, whereas those of the control groups were 3.8 cm, 14 roots, and 0.28 g, respectively.

Question_3876.Context: The Pt gene encoding the polyamine transporter protein was examined in cucumber roots after treatment with DJ bacteria under salinity-alkalinity stress. How was the expression of the Pt gene affected?
Question_3876.Question: How was the expression of the Pt gene affected?
Question_3876.Source: The expression of Pt gene encoding polyamine transporter protein was sharply up-regulated in cucumber roots after treatment with DJ bacteria under salinity-alkalinity stress; the expression was more than tenfold higher than that in the control groups.

Question_3877.Context: Antioxidant enzyme activities were measured in cucumber seedlings under salinity-alkalinity conditions. How were the enzyme activities of POD, SOD, and CAT affected in the cucumber seedlings?
Question_3877.Question: How were the enzyme activities of POD, SOD, and CAT affected in the cucumber seedlings?
Question_3877.Source: The enzyme activities of POD, SOD, and CAT in cucumber seedlings were higher compared to those in the control groups (p < 0.01).

Question_3878.Context: The study investigated the growth promotion effects of DJ bacteria on cucumber seedlings under salinity-alkalinity stress. How did the lateral root number in the DJ treatment groups compare to the control groups?
Question_3878.Question: How did the lateral root number in the DJ treatment groups compare to the control groups?
Question_3878.Source: The stem height, number of lateral roots, and fresh weight of cucumber seedlings in the DJ treatment groups were 6.0 cm, 17 roots, and 0.42 g, respectively, whereas those of the control groups were 3.8 cm, 14 roots, and 0.28 g, respectively, with a notable difference between two cohorts (p < 0.01).

Question_3879.Context: The study examined the adaptation of DJ bacteria to alkaline conditions. How did the biomass growth trend of DJ bacteria differ under different pH conditions?
Question_3879.Question: How did the biomass growth trend of DJ bacteria differ under different pH conditions?
Question_3879.B: Higher under neutral and alkaline conditions
Question_3879.Source: Results showed that the biomass growth trend of DJ bacteria was basically the same under neutral and alkaline culture conditions and was significantly higher than that under acidic culture conditions.

Question_3880.Context: The study investigated the swimming motility of DJ bacteria in salinity-alkalinity conditions. How did the diameter of the colonies on the salinity-alkalinity medium compare to the ADF medium?
Question_3880.Question: How did the diameter of the colonies on the salinity-alkalinity medium compare to the ADF medium?
Question_3880.Source: The average diameter of the colonies on the salinity-alkalinity medium was 3.3 cm, and this was significantly different (p < 0.01) from that (1.9 cm) of the control group.

Question_3881.Context: The study conducted a swim plate assay to analyze the chemotactic response of DJ bacteria. How did the swimming motility of DJ bacteria in salinity-alkalinity medium compare to the ADF medium?
Question_3881.Question: How did the swimming motility of DJ bacteria in salinity-alkalinity medium compare to the ADF medium?
Question_3881.Source: The swimming motility of DJ bacteria in salinity-alkalinity medium was greater than that in ADF medium, indicating that DJ bacteria adapted to grow in salinity-alkalinity conditions.

Question_3882.Context: The study focuses on the durability of fluoropolymer hydrophobic coatings against falling droplets. They simulate raindrops to damage samples with various thicknesses of Cytop (CTX-809SP2) and then heat them to recover their hydrophobicity.
Question_3882.Question: What is the purpose of simulating raindrops in the study?
Question_3882.A: To evaluate the effect of temperature on hydrophobic coatings
Question_3882.B: To examine the impact of repeated damage on hydrophobic coatings
Question_3882.C: To assess the recovery limitations of hydrophobic coatings
Question_3882.D: To measure the thickness of hydrophobic coatings
Question_3882.Source: Devices such as smart self-cleaning lens or droplet-based energy generators are open-air electrowetting-on-dielectric (EWOD) devices, which are applications that utilize falling droplets. Therefore, the hydrophobic coatings of these devices are exposed to environment factors such as raindrop, and it is necessary to examine the durability of hydrophobic coatings in similar environments and the effectiveness of recovery.

Question_3883.Context: The study evaluates the long-term durability of hydrophobic coatings for open-air EWOD devices. They subject Cytop (CTX-809SP2) to a continuous damage-recovery cycle and analyze the EWOD actuation performance.
Question_3883.Question: What is the main focus of the study regarding hydrophobic coatings?
Question_3883.A: To determine the optimal thickness for hydrophobic coatings
Question_3883.B: To investigate the impact of repeated damage-recovery cycles on hydrophobic coatings
Question_3883.C: To compare the performance of different types of hydrophobic coatings
Question_3883.D: To analyze the chemical composition of hydrophobic coatings
Question_3883.Source: This study evaluates the long-term durability of hydrophobic coatings for open-air EWOD devices. Cytop (CTX-809SP2), a fluoropolymer-based hydrophobic coating, was subjected to a continuous damage-recovery cycle, and the EWOD actuation performance was analyzed as a function of hydrophobic coating thickness in each cycle.

Question_3884.Context: The study involves damaging samples with falling droplets and then heating them to recover their hydrophobicity. They repeat this damage-recovery cycle several times to evaluate the long-term durability of hydrophobic coatings.
Question_3884.Question: What method is used to recover the hydrophobicity of damaged samples?
Question_3884.A: Heating on a hot plate at 100°C for 12 hours
Question_3884.B: Heating on a hot plate at 200°C for 24 hours
Question_3884.C: Exposing to UV light for 6 hours
Question_3884.D: Soaking in a chemical solution for 48 hours
Question_3884.Source: The samples are then heated on a hot plate at 200 °C for 24 h to recover their hydrophobicity damaged by falling droplets.

Question_3885.Context: The study compares the EWOD performance of damaged and undamaged hydrophobic coatings. They measure the change in contact angle of droplets by increasing and decreasing voltage.
Question_3885.Question: How is the EWOD actuation performance measured in the study?
Question_3885.A: By analyzing the color change of the hydrophobic coatings
Question_3885.B: By measuring the change in contact angle of droplets with varying voltage
Question_3885.C: By counting the number of droplets on the surface
Question_3885.D: By observing the surface roughness under a microscope
Question_3885.Source: All the EWOD experiments are performed using a function generator and amplifier with a frequency of 1 kHz to measure the change in CA of the droplets by sequentially increasing the voltage from 0 Vrms to 100 Vrms and decreasing it back to 0 Vrms, in 10 Vrms increments.

Question_3886.Context: The study evaluates the performance of hydrophobic coatings over repeated damage-recovery cycles. They observe the change in contact angle and contact angle hysteresis of water droplets on the surface of the coatings.
Question_3886.Question: What is the observed trend in the EWOD performance after the second damage-recovery cycle?
Question_3886.A: The thickest sample shows the best performance
Question_3886.B: The thinnest sample shows the best performance
Question_3886.D: The performance degrades for all samples
Question_3886.Source: For the 0.1 μm thick sample after the second cycle, the CA of the dewetted droplet after the EWOD actuation recovered by about 87 % compared to the initial CA before the EWOD actuation, while the 0.5 μm thick sample recovered by 88 %. The 1.0 μm thick sample recovered about 95 %, performing 8 % better than the 0.1 μm thick sample and 7 % better than the 0.5 μm thick sample.

Question_3887.Context: The study examines the recovery limitations of hydrophobic coatings over multiple damage-recovery cycles. They measure the contact angle and contact angle hysteresis of water droplets on the surface of the coatings.
Question_3887.Question: What is the conclusion regarding the recovery limitations of hydrophobic coatings after the third damage-recovery cycle?
Question_3887.A: The recovery is fully successful for all samples
Question_3887.B: The recovery is limited for all samples
Question_3887.C: The recovery is most successful for the thinnest sample
Question_3887.D: The recovery is most successful for the thickest sample
Question_3887.Source: After the third cycle, no dewetting of the droplets is observed after the EWOD actuation, which means breakdown of the hydrophobic coating, regardless of its thickness. Therefore, it concludes that the damage-recovery of the hydrophobic coating in this falling droplets experiment can not fully perform for three cycles, regardless of the thickness of the hydrophobic coating.

Question_3888.Context: The study analyzes the surface morphology of hydrophobic coatings after repeated damage-recovery cycles. They use atomic force microscopy to observe changes in the surface roughness.
Question_3888.Question: What is the effect of repeated damage-recovery cycles on the surface roughness of hydrophobic coatings?
Question_3888.A: The surface becomes smoother with each cycle
Question_3888.B: The surface becomes rougher with each cycle
Question_3888.Source: The roughness gradually increased with each repeated damage-recovery cycle. The high roughness of the surface makes it difficult for water droplets to slide easily. Therefore, it is likely to have had a significant impact on the increase in CAH.

Question_3889.Context: The study investigates the recovery of hydrophobic coatings after being damaged by falling droplets. They measure the contact angle and contact angle hysteresis of water droplets on the surface of the coatings.
Question_3889.Question: What is the recovery rate of contact angle and contact angle hysteresis after heating the damaged samples?
Question_3889.A: CA recovered about 98% and CAH about 81%
Question_3889.B: CA recovered about 90% and CAH about 50%
Question_3889.C: CA recovered about 75% and CAH about 90%
Question_3889.D: CA recovered about 85% and CAH about 70%
Question_3889.Source: Regardless of the hydrophobic coating thickness, CA and CAH are measured to average 114° and 16° after heating. The experiment shows that CA and CAH recovered about 98% and 81%, respectively, compared to before damage.

Question_3890.Context: The study evaluates the impact of repeated damage-recovery cycles on the EWOD performance of hydrophobic coatings. They measure the change in contact angle of droplets with varying voltage before and after damage-recovery cycles.
Question_3890.Question: What is the observed trend in the EWOD performance after the first damage-recovery cycle?
Question_3890.A: The damaged samples show improved performance
Question_3890.B: The damaged samples show degraded performance
Question_3890.C: The damaged samples show no change in performance
Question_3890.D: The undamaged samples show degraded performance
Question_3890.Source: This experiment shows that the samples after the first damage-recovery cycle showed no difference in EWOD performance compared to the undamaged samples, and the difference in the degree of damage based on the hydrophobic coating thickness was not observed in the first damage-recovery cycle.

Question_3891.Context: The study focuses on the recovery limitations of hydrophobic coatings over multiple damage-recovery cycles. They measure the contact angle and contact angle hysteresis of water droplets on the surface of the coatings.
Question_3891.Question: What is the effect of the third damage-recovery cycle on the contact angle hysteresis of hydrophobic coatings?
Question_3891.Source: After the third cycle, no dewetting of the droplets is observed after the EWOD actuation, which means breakdown of the hydrophobic coating, regardless of its thickness. Therefore, it concludes that the damage-recovery of the hydrophobic coating in this falling droplets experiment can not fully perform for three cycles, regardless of the thickness of the hydrophobic coating.

Question_3902.Context: Understanding the thermal conductivity of composites made from polymers and graphene nanoplatelets is crucial for various applications.
Question_3902.Question: What is one of the key advantages of composites of graphene nanoplatelets and polymers in terms of heat dissipation?
Question_3902.A: Enhanced thermal conductivity in all directions
Question_3902.B: Reduced thermal conductivity compared to pure polymers
Question_3902.Source: Composites of graphene nanoplatelets (GNP) and polymers continue to arouse great interest as possible route to dissipating heat, thus extending the in-service life of the final product.

Question_3903.Context: Flexible nanotechnology is being explored for the production of foldable and portable electronic devices.
Question_3903.Question: Why is heat dissipation a concern in scaled-down electronic devices?
Question_3903.C: To ensure efficient operation and prevent thermal degradation
Question_3903.D: To reduce the weight of the devices
Question_3903.Source: Indeed, the excess heat trapped inside the object might lead to thermal degradation.

Question_3904.Context: The phonons in crystalline materials propagate differently compared to polymeric systems.
Question_3904.Question: How do phonons propagate in a crystalline material?
Question_3904.A: As harmonic waves with no energy loss
Question_3904.Source: In a crystalline material (regular homogeneous structure) the phonons propagates as harmonic waves and the heat dissipates with no energy loss along the thermal path.

Question_3905.Context: Flexible devices are becoming more popular due to their portability and environmental benefits.
Question_3905.Question: What is driving technology companies towards the manufacture of soft substrates?
Question_3905.B: Requirement for foldable and recyclable devices
Question_3905.Source: The need for flexible devices driven by the exigence to fulfil requirements from an immense variety of customers is pushing technology companies towards the manufacture of soft substrates, which can be folded, rolled, are portable and environmentally friendly.

Question_3906.Context: Fused Deposition Modelling (FDM) is considered an innovative solution for thermal management in small objects.
Question_3906.Question: What is a potential limitation of FDM for large-scale production?
Question_3906.Source: While there are controversial opinions on the limitations of FDM for large-scale and high volume production (e.g. long production times, and expensive printers required).

Question_3907.Question: What is one of the challenges mentioned in the text related to the printing of composites by FDM?
Question_3907.Source: In this mini-review, we describe the many technical challenges that remain to successful printing of these composites by FDM, including orientation effects.

Question_3908.Context: The role of different factors in determining the thermal conductivity of composite products made by FDM is discussed.
Question_3908.Question: Which factor plays a role in determining the thermal conductivity of composite products made by FDM?
Question_3908.Source: We also compare these initial reports with those on FDM of other and related carbonaceous fillers, such as multi-walled carbon nanotubes and carbon fibre.

Question_3909.Question: What makes FDM a valid alternative for the manufacture of (micro)-electronic components?
Question_3909.Source: FDM is an innovative solution to the manufacture of small objects where effective thermal management is required and it is a valid alternative for the manufacture of (micro)-electronic components.

Question_3912.Context: Nanozymes mimic the function of enzymes in intracellular chemical reactions. They can generate or degrade specific biomolecules to regulate cellular behaviors. Two approaches for utilizing nanozymes in intracellular chemistry have been reported.
Question_3912.Question: What are the two approaches for utilizing nanozymes in intracellular chemistry?
Question_3912.Source: Biomimetic catalysis replicates the identical reactions of natural enzymes, and bioorthogonal catalysis enables chemistries inaccessible in cells.

Question_3913.Context: Nanozymes are employed to attain specific catalysis in cells either to mimic enzymatic mechanisms and kinetics or expand inaccessible chemistries.
Question_3913.Question: What is the purpose of employing nanozymes in cells?
Question_3913.Source: Nanozymes delivered inside cells have catalyzed chemical reactions that can generate or degrade biomolecules or functional molecules, inducing desired cellular behaviors.

Question_3914.Context: Nanozymes can be categorized as biomimetic, replicating catalytic functions using natural enzymes, or bioorthogonal, which cannot occur in biological processes.
Question_3914.Question: How are nanozymes categorized based on their catalytic functions?
Question_3914.A: As natural enzymes and artificial enzymes
Question_3914.Source: Catalysis using nanozymes for intended biochemical cellular reactions can be categorized as biomimetic, which replicates catalytic functions using natural enzymes, and bioorthogonal, which cannot occur in biological processes.

Question_3915.Context: BMNZs possess intrinsic enzyme-like activities, including analogs to peroxidase, oxidase, catalase, superoxide dismutase, and hydrolase activity.
Question_3915.Question: What are the enzyme-like activities possessed by BMNZs?
Question_3915.Source: BMNZs possess intrinsic enzyme-like activities, including analogs to peroxidase, oxidase, catalase, superoxide dismutase, and hydrolase activity.

Question_3916.Context: BMNZs with peroxidase-like activity accelerate the oxidation of substrates by catalyzing H2O2 and follow the Michaelis–Menten kinetics and ping–pong mechanism.
Question_3916.Question: What mechanism do BMNZs with peroxidase-like activity follow?
Question_3916.Source: BMNZs with peroxidase-like activities follow the Michaelis–Menten kinetics and ping–pong mechanism.

Question_3917.Context: BMNZs with oxidase-like activity catalyze the oxidation of substrates at the expense of molecular oxygen and other oxidizing reagents.
Question_3917.Question: What is the primary requirement for BMNZs with oxidase-like activity to catalyze oxidation?
Question_3917.Source: OXD is a natural enzyme that can catalyze the oxidation of substrates at the expense of molecular oxygen and other oxidizing reagents.

Question_3918.Context: BMNZs with catalase-like activity promote the breakdown of H2O2 into H2O and O2, following the Michaelis–Menten kinetics.
Question_3918.Question: What is the primary function of BMNZs with catalase-like activity?
Question_3918.Source: CAT-like BMNZs follow the Michaelis–Menten kinetics and promote the breakdown of H2O2 into H2O and O2.

Question_3919.Context: SOD-like BMNZs catalyze the dismutation of superoxide radicals into O2 and H2O2, providing antioxidant defense against oxidative stress.
Question_3919.Question: What is the primary function of SOD-like BMNZs?
Question_3919.B: Catalyze the dismutation of superoxide radicals
Question_3919.D: Catalyze the reduction of molecular oxygen
Question_3919.Source: SOD-like BMNZs catalyze the dismutation of superoxide radicals, such as HOO· and ·O2 –, into O2 and H2O2.

Question_3920.Context: BMNZs that mimic hydrolytic enzymes can facilitate reactions by acting as Lewis acid catalysts or activating H2O molecules for nucleophilic attack.
Question_3920.Question: How do BMNZs mimic hydrolytic enzymes in facilitating reactions?
Question_3920.C: By acting as Lewis acid catalysts
Question_3920.D: By acting as Lewis base catalysts
Question_3920.Source: BMNZs that can mimic hydrolytic enzymes can facilitate the reaction either by acting as Lewis acid catalysts or by activating H2O molecules to produce nucleophilic attack reagents for substrate hydrolysis.

Question_3921.Context: Various nanomaterials with specific features are used to facilitate intracellular catalysis with BMNZs and BONZs.
Question_3921.Question: What is the role of nanomaterials in facilitating intracellular catalysis with nanozymes?
Question_3921.Source: For both nanozymes, various nanomaterials and catalytic metals with specific features may be used to facilitate intracellular catalysis.

Question_3922.Context: The paper discusses strain energy decomposition methods in phase field fracture models and evaluates their performance with benchmark problems. In the first benchmark, the predicted mechanical behavior of cracked material is compared.
Question_3922.Question: What is the goal of the work described in the paper?
Question_3922.A: To assess the performance of strain decomposition methods
Question_3922.B: To develop a new strain energy decomposition method
Question_3922.C: To compare the performance of different fracture models
Question_3922.D: To study the impact of stress decomposition on fracture behavior
Question_3922.Source: The goal of this work is to facilitate the choice of strain decomposition method by assessing the performance of three existing methods (spectral decomposition of the stress or the strain and deviatoric decomposition of the strain) and one new method (deviatoric decomposition of the stress) with several benchmark problems.

Question_3923.Context: The paper discusses various benchmark problems used to evaluate the performance of strain energy decomposition methods in phase field fracture models.
Question_3923.Question: What type of benchmark problems were used to compare the performance of the strain decomposition methods?
Question_3923.C: Both quasi-static and dynamic benchmark cases
Question_3923.Source: In each benchmark problem, we compare the performance of the four methods using both qualitative and quantitative metrics. In the first benchmark, we compare the predicted mechanical behavior of cracked material. We then use four quasi-static benchmark cases: a single edge notched tension test, a single edge notched shear test, a three-point bending test, and a L-shaped panel test. Finally, we use two dynamic benchmark cases: a dynamic tensile fracture test and a dynamic shear fracture test.

Question_3924.Context: The paper discusses the performance of different strain energy decomposition methods in phase field fracture models under various loading conditions.
Question_3924.Question: Which strain decomposition method correctly localizes tensile strain within the cracked material?
Question_3924.Source: All four methods correctly predict all of the tensile strain localized within the cracked material, the spectral methods correctly predict cracked material can support compressive stress, and the deviatoric methods correctly predict localization of shear strain within cracked material.

Question_3925.Context: The paper evaluates the performance of strain energy decomposition methods in phase field fracture models under different loading conditions.
Question_3925.Question: Which strain decomposition method accurately allows cracked material to fully support a compressive stress?
Question_3925.Source: The two spectral methods accurately allow cracked material to fully support a compressive stress, while the deviatoric methods only support a portion of the compressive stress.

Question_3926.Context: The paper discusses the impact of strain energy decomposition methods on fracture behavior under different loading conditions.
Question_3926.Question: Which strain decomposition method accurately localizes shear strain within the cracked material?
Question_3926.Source: The deviatoric methods accurately localize the shear strain within the crack, while the spectral methods allow the crack to support some shear stress.

Question_3927.Context: The paper evaluates the performance of strain energy decomposition methods in phase field fracture models under various loading conditions.
Question_3927.Question: Which strain decomposition method accurately predicts the crack path in a three-point bending test?
Question_3927.Source: The two spectral methods accurately predict the crack path in a three-point bending test, while the two deviatoric methods require that the load be applied across at least seven nodes for the crack to propagate.

Question_3928.Context: The paper discusses the performance of different strain energy decomposition methods in phase field fracture models under various loading conditions.
Question_3928.Question: Which strain decomposition method predicts no crack propagation in a mixed mode L-shaped panel fracture case?
Question_3928.Source: In the L-shaped panel mixed mode case, the spectral methods provide reasonable predictions, while the deviatoric methods do not predict any crack formation.

Question_3929.Context: The paper evaluates the performance of strain energy decomposition methods in phase field fracture models under different loading conditions.
Question_3929.Question: Which strain decomposition method predicts similar crack paths in a quasi-static shear test?
Question_3929.Source: For the quasi-static shear case, the two deviatoric methods predict similar crack paths, while the spectral methods allow the crack to support some shear stress.

Question_3930.Context: The paper discusses the impact of strain energy decomposition methods on fracture behavior under different loading conditions.
Question_3930.Question: Which strain decomposition method predicts similar crack paths in a dynamic shear test?
Question_3930.Source: The two spectral methods again predict the correct crack paths and similar crack propagation rates.

Question_3931.Context: The paper evaluates the performance of strain energy decomposition methods in phase field fracture models under different loading conditions.
Question_3931.Question: Which strain decomposition method predicts the correct crack paths and similar crack propagation rates in a dynamic tensile fracture test?
Question_3931.Source: The crack paths from the four methods are all very similar. The crack length evolution from the four methods is also very similar.

Question_3932.Context: The paper discusses the implications of the anisotropic and long-range nature of correlation functions for the pinning of dislocations of arbitrary orientation.
Question_3932.Question: What is the suggested approach to address the problem of solute hardening in compositionally complex alloys?
Question_3932.A: Treating the alloy as an effective medium with random distribution of dilatation and compression centers.
Question_3932.B: Direct summation of the interaction energies between dislocations and solutes.
Question_3932.C: Ignoring the effects of volumetric misfit of atoms of different species.
Question_3932.D: Applying external forces to dislocations to overcome pinning energy minima.
Question_3932.Source: It has been suggested that this problem can be addressed by treating the alloy as an effective medium containing a random distribution of dilatation and compression centers representing the volumetric misfit of atoms of different species.

Question_3933.Context: The paper discusses the theory of dislocations interacting with atomic-scale obstacles in compositionally complex alloy systems.
Question_3933.Question: What is the role of statistical theories in the context of dislocation pinning by atomic-scale obstacles?
Question_3933.A: They have no relevance in understanding dislocation behavior.
Question_3933.B: They provide insights into the pinning of dislocations by atomic-scale obstacles.
Question_3933.C: They are only applicable to edge dislocations.
Question_3933.D: They focus solely on kinetic effects.
Question_3933.Source: From a theoretical viewpoint, statistical theories of dislocation pinning by atomic-scale obstacles have attracted the interest of statistical physicists.

Question_3934.Context: The paper discusses the scaling theory of elastic lines in static random fields.
Question_3934.Question: How is the dislocation envisaged in the scaling theory of elastic lines?
Question_3934.B: As an elastic line with line tension.
Question_3934.C: As a continuous line with no tension.
Question_3934.Source: We envisage the dislocation as an elastic line of line tension 0 b2 where is the shear modulus, b the length of the Burgers vector.

Question_3935.Context: The paper discusses the statistical properties of local shear stresses in random alloys.
Question_3935.Question: What is the correlation function for the shear stress in the longitudinal direction in the effective medium with random volumetric misfit?
Question_3935.Source: The correlation functions in the shear direction (’longitudinal’ correlation function L) is derived as L(u) = 30u^3 - 12u^2 erf(u/2) + 1 - 6u^2 exp(-u^2/4).

Question_3936.Context: The paper discusses the pinning of edge dislocations.
Question_3936.Question: What is the pinning length for a perfect edge dislocation in a hypothetical Al0.5Mg0.5 fcc random solid solution?
Question_3936.Source: With these parameters we obtain for a pure edge dislocation Lp = 32.9 Å.

Question_3937.Context: The paper discusses the pinning of screw dislocations.

Question_3948.Context: The paper discusses the production of renewable energy from food waste in South Korea.

Question_3952.Context: The study focuses on the properties of La-doped BaSnO3 (BLSO) films grown on different substrates for electromagnetic shielding transparent conductors.

Question_3958.Source: The 5% − BLSOMgO MgAl2O4 film showed the lowest level of electron scattering and the highest conductivity, which was 1000-fold higher compared to films without the template layer.

Question_3959.Context: The study investigates the effect of La concentration on the SE of BLSO films.

Question_3961.Source: The carrier density of BLSOMgO MgAl2O4 increased from 4.2 to 14.1 × 10^20 cm−3 as the La concentration decreased.

Question_3971.Context: The paper discusses the response of different system realizations.

Question_4002.Context: The paper discusses the thermoelectric performance of SnSe and its dependence on the low-energy electron band structure.
Question_4002.Question: What determines the thermoelectric performance of a material according to the paper?
Question_4002.Source: Here S, σ, T, and κ are the Seebeck coefficient, electric conductivity, temperature, and thermal conductivity, respectively, while S2σ is called a power factor (PF). One of the ultimate goals in the research of thermoelectric materials is to achieve a high ZT value, which is generally considered a challenging task because the physical parameters comprising ZT are correlated and often act adversely on each other.

Question_4003.Context: The paper mentions a specific method to optimize the electrical and thermal properties of thermoelectric materials.
Question_4003.Question: What is mentioned as an effective strategy to optimize the electrical and thermal properties of thermoelectric materials?
Question_4003.Source: One effective strategy to optimize both the electrical and thermal properties is defect engineering, which can simultaneously increase the charge carrier concentration and reduce the lattice thermal conductivity in the material.

Question_4004.Context: The paper discusses the band structure of SnSe and its relation to thermoelectric performance.
Question_4004.Question: What is the band structure of SnSe characterized by?
Question_4004.Source: It has attracted recent research interest owing to its high ZT value, due to the ultrahigh PF, which is attributed to a multi-valley valence band maximum (VBM) and band renormalization.

Question_4005.Context: The paper discusses the effect of cooling rate during crystal growth on the electron band structure of SnSe.
Question_4005.Question: How does the cooling rate during crystal growth affect the charge carrier density of SnSe?
Question_4005.Source: With increasing cooling rate to 5 K/h, the overall multi-valley band shifts toward higher binding energy, indicating that the cooling rate tunes the charge carrier density of SnSe.

Question_4006.Context: The paper discusses the role of Sn vacancies in tuning the electron band structure of SnSe.
Question_4006.Question: What effect do Sn vacancies have on the electron band structure of SnSe?
Question_4006.A: Shift the valence band maximum to higher energy
Question_4006.B: Shift the valence band maximum to lower energy
Question_4006.Source: With increasing x, the overall multi-valley VBM shifts toward lower binding energy.

Question_4007.Context: The paper discusses the correlation between the electron band structure and the thermoelectric performance of SnSe.
Question_4007.Question: What is the correlation between the electron band structure and the thermoelectric performance of SnSe?
Question_4007.Source: This finding suggests that the high PF, observed in hole-doped SnSe, is closely correlated with the charge carrier density (hole concentrations), i.e., the population of Sn vacancies.

Question_4008.Context: The paper discusses the effect of cooling rate on the thermoelectric power factor of SnSe.
Question_4008.Question: How does the thermoelectric power factor of SnSe change with increasing cooling rate?
Question_4008.Source: EVBM does not show a notable change up to a cooling rate of 3K/h. When the cooling rate further increases, EVBM decreases, indicating that SnSe gradually has less hole doping due to Sn vacancies.

Question_4009.Context: The paper discusses the effective mass of multiple hole bands in SnSe.
Question_4009.Question: What is the effective mass of the α band along the Γ-Y direction for a crystal growth cooling rate of 0.5 K/h?
Question_4009.Source: Parabolic fitting to the top of the α, β, and γ bands shown in Fig. 2 corresponding to a cooling rate of 0.5 K/h confirms the light effective mass of m*α ΓX = 0.19 ± 0.02 me.

Question_4010.Context: The paper discusses the fabrication of an intrinsic defect-induced high-efficiency thermoelectric phase of SnSe.
Question_4010.Question: What is suggested as a viable route towards engineering the thermoelectric performance of SnSe?
Question_4010.Source: These findings suggest a simple but efficient way to fabricate an intrinsic defect-induced high-efficiency thermoelectric phase of SnSe and provide a viable route toward the engineering of thermoelectric performance via the sample growth condition without an additional ex-situ process.

Question_4011.Context: The paper discusses the research conducted on the electron band structure of SnSe.

Question_4011.Source: The electron band structure of SnSe was calculated utilizing the DFT implemented in full-potential linearized augmented plane wave package.

Question_4102.Context: Understanding and manipulating exciton transport in TMD monolayers can lead to the progress of the next generation electronic and optoelectronic device. However, the electrical control of the neutral excitons is significantly limited due to their charge neutral property. In contrast to the neutral excitons, the transport of charged excitons, which is a Fermi polaron formed by Coulomb attraction between the exciton and surrounding electrons can be driven by an in-plane electric field. Therefore, charged exciton-based optoelectronic devices are expected with the operation principles analogous to that of the conventional electronic devices.
Question_4102.Question: What is the primary factor that enables the transport of charged excitons in TMD monolayers?
Question_4102.Source: The behavior of charged excitons is governed by the electrostatic potential, while IX are influenced by the quantum confined Stark effect.

Question_4105.Context: TMDs have remarkable sustainability to the applied strain with exciton stability at room temperature, which provides unique platforms for continuously modifying the electronic and optical characteristics. The generation of strain-gradient leads to the local modification of the exciton density, as the exciton current flows toward a low bandgap energy. Therefore, various strain-gradient geometries have been suggested for the specific applications, such as harvesting the photon energy as a form of excitons and controlling the exciton current for the exciton integrated circuits. Recently, Lee et al. suggested the tunable device enabling the controlled wrinkle formation of WS2 monolayer.
Question_4105.Question: What effect does strain gradient have on the exciton density?
Question_4105.D: Has no impact on the exciton transport
Question_4105.Source: The generation of strain-gradient leads to the local modification of the exciton density, as the exciton current flows toward a low bandgap energy.

Question_4108.Context: The exciton transport as a coupled form with SPP exhibits the potential for the development of plasmonic optical interconnects and circuits. The plasmon-exciton coupling enables the long-range transport of exciton emission while maintaining intriguing optical characteristics of 2D TMDs, such as valley degree of freedom and indirect bandgap lasing. In addition, coupling to plasmon leads to the concentration of the electromagnetic fields down to the sub-diffraction-limit, enhancing the degree of integration in circuit applications. The long-range exciton transport mediated by the SPP has been facilitated by exploiting cascaded exciton energy transfer within a lateral TMD heterostructure.
Question_4108.Question: What is the primary advantage of coupling excitons with surface plasmon polaritons (SPP)?
Question_4108.Source: The plasmon-exciton coupling enables the long-range transport of exciton emission while maintaining intriguing optical characteristics of 2D TMDs.

Question_4111.Context: Photonic systems are primarily characterized by their optical responses based on key degrees of freedom, which include frequency, wavevector, polarization, and phase. By integrating a custom-designed photonic cavity structure considering the exciton resonances of 2D materials, it becomes feasible to couple excitons with specific photonic modes. This capability has various applications in exciton transport, such as extending the propagation distance and enabling directional propagation of exciton emission without applying external stimulus. In addition to the conventional methods, recent attempts have been increasing to utilize new degree of freedom of photonic systems, such as chirality and topology.
Question_4111.Question: What is the advantage of coupling excitons with specific photonic modes within photonic cavity structures?
Question_4111.Source: By coupling various photonic cavity structures, considering the exciton resonances of two-dimensional semiconductors, it led to excitons coupling with specific photonic modes. This phenomenon facilitated the realization of low-loss and long-range exciton transport.

Question_4112.Context: In the field of molecular sciences, what is a key application area for quantum computing?
Question_4112.Question: What is a key application area for quantum computing in the molecular sciences?
Question_4112.Source: Molecular science is a key application area for quantum computing as the quantum dance of electrons and nuclei in molecules occurs on the nanometer scale, and must be described by a quantum model.

Question_4113.Context: What is the primary advantage of the variational quantum eigensolver (VQE) over quantum phase estimation (QPE) for energy evaluation of molecular systems?
Question_4113.Question: What is the primary advantage of the variational quantum eigensolver (VQE) over quantum phase estimation (QPE) for energy evaluation of molecular systems?
Question_4113.B: Limited by ansatz with uncontrollable error
Question_4113.Source: Unlike QPE, which gives the exact FCI energy, VQE gives a variational upper bound on the energy. The accuracy of VQE is thus limited by the ansatz it adopts.

Question_4114.C: Difficulty in preparing the vibrational basis
Question_4114.Source: Another challenge of applying quantum algorithms for dynamics is that one needs to carefully think what to measure given the limited information one can obtain from a wave function.

Question_4116.Context: What is a common method used in traditional quantum chemistry for studying ensemble of molecular structures to obtain free energy contributions?
Question_4116.Question: What is a common method used in traditional quantum chemistry for studying ensemble of molecular structures to obtain free energy contributions?
Question_4116.Source: In traditional computational chemistry, one can use Monte Carlo sampling or classical molecular dynamics to study an ensemble of molecular structures. This approach allows one to obtain all four free energy contributions and their couplings in one shot.

Question_4118.Context: What is a key difference between quantum phase estimation (QPE) and variational quantum eigensolver (VQE) algorithms for energy evaluation of molecular systems?
Question_4118.Question: What is a key difference between quantum phase estimation (QPE) and variational quantum eigensolver (VQE) algorithms for energy evaluation of molecular systems?
Question_4118.Source: QPE can reach unlimited precision using any initial state of non-negligible overlap with the true ground state, while VQE's precision depends directly on the trial state.

Question_4119.Source: Machine learning, as a data-driven approach, is expected to generate new insights from massive existing quantum chemistry data using various neural network models.

Question_4132.Context: The paper discusses the evolution and performance of polymer MRR design for ultrasound detection.
Question_4132.Question: What is a key advantage of using polymer micro-ring resonators (MRRs) for ultrasound detection?
Question_4132.Source: In particular, polymer micro-ring resonators (MRRs) in the form of integrated photonic circuits (IPC) enable significant reduction for the sensing area to 80 μm in diameter, while maintaining highly sensitive ultrasound detection with noise equivalent pressure (NEP) of 0.49 Pa and a broad detection frequency range up to 250 MHz.

Question_4133.Question: Which fabrication method was used to achieve a Q-factor of 1.0 × 105 at 1.55 μm for the polymer MRR ultrasound detector?
Question_4133.Source: They further improved the Q-factor of the MRR from 3.5 × 104 to 4.6 × 104 by changing the protection material from PDMS to the low refractive index polymer (MY-131-MC, MY Polymer).

Question_4134.Question: What is the axial resolution achieved in photoacoustic imaging using the polymer MRR ultrasound detector?

Question_4183.D: It boosts the levels of sugars in tea leaves

Question_4202.Context: The paper discusses the fabrication of a 3D hierarchically structured polyaniline nanoweb (3D HPN) for capturing drug-resistant bacteria from the skin surface.

Question_4212.Context: The paper discusses the preparation of NdFeB powders filled polymeric matrix (PEEK) and their use in 3D printing to produce high-performance magnets. The influence of the filler on the main thermomechanical properties of the resulting composites was evaluated.

Question_4212.B: Increasing the filler amount in the composite

Question_4212.D: Reducing the amount of PEEK in the composite

Question_4213.Source: PEEK-NdFeB filaments were produced with three percentages of filler amount (i.e. 25, 50, and 75 wt%).

Question_4214.Context: The paper discusses the thermal stability of the printed parts and the effects of the printing process on the material properties.

Question_4214.A: The first layer had higher crystallinity than the upper layers

Question_4214.D: The first layer had no crystallinity

Question_4215.A: Higher crystallinity in the printed parts

Question_4216.Question: What effect did the presence of irregular edges on the particles have on the mechanical properties of the printed parts?

Question_4218.Context: The paper discusses the thermal degradation of the PEEK matrix during the printing process and its impact on the magnetic properties of the printed parts.

Question_4218.Source: The Nd and Fe content was found to be low and the oxygen content high, suggesting the formation of species coming from oxidation reaction.

Question_4220.Context: The paper discusses the feasibility of using PEEK-NdFeB composite filaments in 3D printing for high-performance magnets.

Question_4220.Source: Energy products of 130 J/m3 for PEEK_25NdFeB demonstrated the feasibility of the magnetic 3D printed composite with PEEK.

Question_4221.Context: The paper concludes by discussing the need for further optimization of the printing process to develop magnets suitable for space applications.

Question_4221.Source: The major finding was considered the presence of a not negligible amount of porosity and, in the case of PEEK_50NdFeB sample, the lack of filler orientation.

Question_4273.Source: 5-Methyl furfural, a product of the Maillard reaction, contributes to sweetness and increases smoke concentration. The content of 5-methyl furfural increased by 286% and 70.4% after fermentation in Hainan and Sichuan tobacco leaves.

Question_4274.Context: The research investigated the dynamic changes in conventional chemical composition, flavor compounds, and bacterial community during the fermentation of cigar tobacco leaves from Hainan and Sichuan provinces in China.
Question_4274.Question: Which bacterial phylum was consistently dominant throughout the fermentation process of Sichuan tobacco leaves?
Question_4274.Source: Differently, Proteobacteria was consistently the dominant phylum throughout the fermentation process of Sichuan tobacco leaves, with relative abundances ranging from 44.90 to 55.22%.

Question_4275.Context: The study explored the bacterial community structures and dominant bacteria in Hainan and Sichuan tobacco leaves during fermentation.
Question_4275.Question: Which bacterial genus was nearly absent at the end of fermentation, indicating a decrease in the woody fragrance of cigar tobacco?
Question_4275.Source: Isophorone, a compound known for its woody fragrance and previously identified as a modifying aromatic substance in cigar leaves, was nearly absent at the end of fermentation, indicating a decrease in the woody fragrance of cigar tobacco.

Question_4276.Context: The study investigated the dynamic changes in conventional chemical composition, flavor compounds, and bacterial community during the fermentation of cigar tobacco leaves from Hainan and Sichuan provinces in China.
Question_4276.Question: Which compound significantly decreased after fermentation and contributes more to the rosey and fruity aroma of cigars?
Question_4276.Source: The content of β-damascenone significantly decreased after fermentation, and it showed an extremely low odor threshold in water according to a previous study, contributing more to the rosey and fruity aroma of cigars.

Question_4277.Context: The research focused on the changes in alkaline aromatic components during cigar tobacco fermentation.
Question_4277.Question: What is a distinguishing characteristic of cigar tobacco compared to flue-cured tobacco?
Question_4277.Source: Unlike flue-cured tobacco, which predominantly contains neutral flavor substances, cigar tobacco is characterized by the prevalence of alkaline flavor substances.

Question_4278.Context: The study explored the bacterial community structures and dominant bacteria in Hainan and Sichuan tobacco leaves during fermentation.
Question_4278.Question: Which bacterial genus was identified as a biomarker for tobacco leaves before fermentation but became undetectable by the end of fermentation?
Question_4278.Source: Pediococcus was identified as a biomarker for tobacco leaves before fermentation, which exhibited a decreasing trend along with the fermentation, and becoming undetectable by the end.

Question_4279.Context: The study investigated the dynamic changes in conventional chemical composition, flavor compounds, and bacterial community during the fermentation of cigar tobacco leaves from Hainan and Sichuan provinces in China.
Question_4279.Question: Which bacterial genus was significantly positively correlated with characteristic volatile flavor substances in fermented low-salt fish?
Question_4279.Source: Stenotrophomonas and Rhodococcus were significantly positively correlated with characteristic volatile flavor substances in fermented low-salt fish.

Question_4280.Context: The study focused on the fermentation of cigar tobacco leaves from Hainan and Sichuan provinces in China.
Question_4280.Question: Which bacterial genus was identified as a core bacterial genus in the fermentation of 'Cabernet Sauvignon' Wine in Ningxia, China?
Question_4280.Source: Rhodococcus was identified as a core bacterial genus in the fermentation of 'Cabernet Sauvignon' Wine in Ningxia, China.

Question_4281.Context: The study explored the bacterial community structures and dominant bacteria in Hainan and Sichuan tobacco leaves during fermentation.
Question_4281.Question: Which bacterial genus was identified as a functional microbe responsible for the production of amino acids and flavor compounds in fermented foods like Suanyu, cheese, and soy sauce?
Question_4281.Source: Kocuria has been reported to be the functional microbe responsible for the production of amino acids and flavor compounds in many fermented foods, such as Suanyu, cheese, and soy sauce.

Question_4282.Context: The text discusses the SIMOX fabrication method for SOI wafers.
Question_4282.Question: What is the high-temperature annealing process in the SIMOX method primarily responsible for?
Question_4282.C: Controlling the thickness of the embedded insulator layer
Question_4282.Source: The resulting SiO2 layer is embedded within the silicon substrate, giving rise to the characteristic SOI structure. This development provided a means to effectively control the thickness of the embedded insulator layer.

Question_4283.Context: The text discusses the advantages of the Smart Cut™ fabrication method for SOI wafers.
Question_4283.Question: What is a notable advantage of the Smart Cut™ technology?
Question_4283.C: Ability to change the materials of the device layer and handle layer
Question_4283.Source: The Smart Cut™ technology grants the ability to change the type of device layer (germanium, silicon carbide, indium phosphate etc.) and handle wafer (sapphire etc.), extending the versatility of this process.

Question_4284.Context: The text discusses the Eltran® fabrication method for SOI wafers.
Question_4284.Question: What is a challenge associated with the Eltran® process?
Question_4284.A: Absence of COP occurrence in the device layer
Question_4284.B: Reflection of the porous silicon roughness
Question_4284.C: High quality device layer due to absence of ion implantation
Question_4284.D: High cost and low yield due to multiple process steps and inherent complexity
Question_4284.Source: High cost and low yield due to multiple process steps and inherent complexity.

Question_4285.Context: The text discusses the BSOI/BESOI fabrication method for SOI wafers.
Question_4285.Question: What is an advantage of the BSOI/BESOI process?
Question_4285.A: Device layer with a thickness more than 10 µm
Question_4285.B: Material wastage due to thinning down
Question_4285.D: Damage during the mechanical grinding process
Question_4285.Source: Device layer with a thickness more than 10 µm. Lower defect density.

Question_4286.Context: The text discusses the structural characterization of SOI wafers.
Question_4286.Question: Which technique is used to determine the surface roughness of SOI wafers?
Question_4286.Source: Surface roughness is typically determined using Atomic Force Microscopy (AFM), where a random area of several µm2 is imaged.

Question_4287.Context: The text discusses the electrical characterization of SOI wafers.
Question_4287.Question: What is the primary purpose of the pseudo-MOSFET technique?
Question_4287.B: To extract mobility and doping concentration
Question_4287.Source: One of the notable advantages of this approach is the ability to operate and analyze the MOSFET characteristics without requiring manufacturing processes like doping or thermal treatments.

Question_4288.Context: The text discusses the electrical characterization of SOI wafers.
Question_4288.Question: Which method is used to extract mobility and doping concentration in SOI wafers?
Question_4288.Source: The Hall effect can be used to extract mobility and doping concentration.

Question_4289.Context: The text discusses the electrical characterization of SOI wafers.
Question_4289.Question: What does the Hall effect allow for in SOI wafers?
Question_4289.Source: Using these parameters, both the mobility and doping concentration can be extracted.

Question_4290.Context: The text discusses the challenges in SOI wafer production.
Question_4290.Question: What is a key challenge in current SOI wafer production methods?
Question_4290.C: Development of technology for batch fabrication
Question_4290.D: Repetitive process for multi-layer SOI wafers
Question_4290.Source: There’s a pressing need for new SOI wafer production methods that can minimize or bypass individually applied steps and allow for the majority of the processes to be carried out via batch fabrication.

Question_4291.Context: The text discusses the conclusion regarding SOI wafer technology.
Question_4291.Question: What is a potential area for improvement in SOI wafer technology?
Question_4291.Source: If a novel production method, different from merely repeating conventional technologies, is developed for crafting multi-layered SOI wafers, it could broaden the spectrum of devices that can be manufactured.

Question_4312.Context: Fruit by-products contain valuable bioactive substances. Phenolic compounds are one of the bioactive substances found in fruit by-products.
Question_4312.Question: What are phenolic compounds chemically characterized by?
Question_4312.A: Aromatic and benzene ring with one or more hydroxide groups
Question_4312.B: Aliphatic structure with multiple hydroxide groups
Question_4312.Source: Chemically, molecular structures with an aromatic and benzene ring, as well as one or more hydroxide groups are called phenolic compounds; these compounds have derivatives with useful properties (glycosides, esters, methyl esters, etc.) (Barba et al. 2014).

Question_4313.Context: Phenolic compounds are abundant in fruit and vegetable wastes. Different extraction methods can influence the total phenolic content in fruit by-products.
Question_4313.Question: Which extraction method was found to be more efficient for extracting phenolic compounds from fruit by-products?
Question_4313.Source: The pressurized hot-water extraction approach seemed to be more efficient than the organic solvent and enzyme-assisted extraction approach (Islam et al. 2021).

Question_4314.Context: Phenolic compounds have antioxidant and antibacterial properties. Some specific phenolic compounds are frequently identified in different fruit by-products.
Question_4314.Question: Which of the following is NOT a frequently identified phenolic compound in fruit by-products?
Question_4314.Source: Among thousands of phenolic compounds, gallic acid, catechin, epicatechin, hydroxycinnamic acids, ferulic acid, quercetin, caffeic, procatechinic, syringic, vanillic acid, dopamine, hydroxy-tyrosol, tyrosol, cyanidin glycosides, L-dopa, p-coumaric acid, syringic acid, mangiferin, rutin, etc. are frequently identified in different FBPs.

Question_4315.Context: Fruit by-products are rich in bioactive compounds. Phenolic compounds are found in significant amounts in various fruit by-products.
Question_4315.Question: Which fruit by-product demonstrated the highest concentration of soluble phenolic compounds?
Question_4315.Source: They found that rambutan peel had the highest concentration of soluble phenolic compounds (12.68 ± 0.76 g/100 g DM) compared to mango seed (8.95 ± 0.36 g/100 g DM).

Question_4316.Context: Phenolic compounds in fruit by-products have antioxidant properties. These compounds can be used as food preservatives.
Question_4316.Question: Which phenolic compound has potential antioxidant, antibacterial, anti-inflammatory, and anticancer properties, and functions as a preservative and a skin protection agent?
Question_4316.Source: For example, ferulic acid has potential antioxidant, antibacterial, anti-inflammatory, and anticancer properties, it functions as a skin protection agent, a preservative, and a cross-linking agent.

Question_4317.A: They are essential compounds in the human diet
Question_4317.B: They are secondary metabolites found in plants
Question_4317.D: They are exclusively found in animal products
Question_4317.Source: Bioactive compounds are also signified as nutraceuticals which reflect their presence with biological significance in the human diet.

Question_4318.Context: Fruit by-products contain bioactive substances with health benefits. Phenolic compounds are part of the bioactive substances found in fruit by-products.
Question_4318.Question: What functions do phenolic compounds exhibit in plants?
Question_4318.Source: For instance, due to their bitterness and astringency they safeguard fruits and vegetables from early eating, attract insects and birds due to their attractive color formation.

Question_4319.Context: Fruit by-products are rich in bioactive compounds. Phenolic compounds are abundant in fruit and vegetable wastes.
Question_4319.Question: What is the chemical characteristic of phenolic compounds?
Question_4319.B: Have a cyclic structure with nitrogen groups
Question_4319.C: Include aromatic and benzene rings with hydroxide groups
Question_4319.Source: Chemically, molecular structures with an aromatic and benzene ring, as well as one or more hydroxide groups are called phenolic compounds.

Question_4320.Question: Which phenolic compound is known for its potential antioxidant, antibacterial, anti-inflammatory, and anticancer properties?
Question_4320.Source: There have been claims that quercetin offers positive health.
